column2: mommyace, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Started this med for change of life depression and anxiety.  It seemed to work very well.  But I had no idea how hard it would be to stop taking. The cost got way too much.  Tried to stop but withdrawal was horrendous.  Even missing a dose was very bad.  Most Drs do NOT understand how bad  it is to stop.  This drug should come with a warning.  I have read so many people have tried to stop and can't.  PLEASE do NOT tae this medicine.  Find another.  Finally, I went to a psychiatrist to help me wean off.  I have been off effexor for one month now.  She had me take Wellbutrin and celexa.  I will have to wean off celexa but nothing like effexor.  The first 2 weeks after I stopped effexor were bad.  I had flu like symptons, aches, nausea dizziness and those brain shocks.  They have lessened.  I am still dizzy quite a bit but it is manageable. I began wellbutrin and celexa 2 weeks prior to stopping effexor.  I was on 75 mg effexor and stopped cold turkey.  Depression is good and I am so glad to not be a slave to that drug.  I plan to wean off all meds in 2 months and see how it goes.  I am starting to feel myself again.  I didn't think I was that numb on effexor but I was.

column2: skattikat, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Before taking this drug it is extremely important to research it first. I was not advised of the horrific withdrawal symptoms. My GP prescribed me this without any discussion or explanation.  I was originally on 150mg per day and then reduced to 75mg (not without problems). Thereafter managed to reduce to 37.5 mg twice per day and then one 37.5mg per day. Each time I reduced I experienced withdrawal.  I recently stopped taking Effexor, on the advice of a Consultant. The withdrawal symptoms are terrible. I have electric shock like feelings in my head which travel down my arms whenever i move my eyes from side to side, extremely sensitive to sound, shaking, nausea, disorientation, vertigo, either insomnia or extreme sleepiness, nightmares, weakness, flu like symptoms. I have now reached day 6 off Effexor and no sign of the  withdrawal abating.  I am now seeking the help of a counsellor to assist me in coping with not only the withdrawal but the terrible mood swings.  My life has completely changed since taking and coming off this drug, and not for the better. I would say to anyone thinking about taking Effexor to think carefully before doing so and be aware of what you are going into.

column2: davidmcclain1971@yahoo.com, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been suffering from severe depression for about 6 years. i have had docs try almost everything on me with no help! the effexor xr cause me severe stomach pain, inability to ejaculate, and made my depression ALOT worse. i had severe thoughts of suicide, could not get out to do anything, and i am an outdoors person. missed the spring crappie fishing, 4 wheeler riding in the mud, just couldnt bring myself to do anything? needless to say i stopped taking it. going back to doc on friday, probably have me try something else, but i just dont know what else there is? i have tried almost everything i have ever heard of and even ones i havent?

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have to say Effexor was THEE WORST drug I've ever taken and i was only taking 75mg! Aside making me feel more depressed, I gained an enormous amount of weight, had blurry vision, felt weak all of the time, restless legs, arms, hands & throat; had less than no sex drive,  and my hair started to fall out (that was the last straw). Getting off of it s u c k s. The side effects were so bad, I was afraid to come off it completely so I cut down to the lowest dose for as long as I could until finally I stopped it altogether...but not before having the worst episode of blind rage I've ever had in my life, followed by anxiety attacks, brain shocks, and dizziness. Took almost two weeks after I stopped the drug completely to not feel any of the things above. Sure, I can be a depressed person (hence, why I take anti-depressants!) but Effexor made me an ultra-depressed crazy person and to be honest, i'm not sure how it has FDA approval. But again..this is just my experience, others have had success.

column2: justme-inME, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking Effexor XR about 4 years ago for menopausal symptoms ,including severe mood swings,hot flashes,anxiety.At first it was great and had all my symptoms under control. Gradually,the side effects started to out weigh the benefits.Extreme dry mouth,inability to cry at any time.(It,s just not normal to not feel sad EVER.)Absolutely no sex drive,which in itself was depressing.Getting off the drug was a horrible experience.The docs never seem to tell you that part of it.I started  at 75 mg/day and was increased to 150 mg.That was not good. I went back down to 75 mg and stayed there for a while.I finally got fed up with "missing life", so I tried to get off the drug.It was a slow ,difficult process.It took over a year, gradually cutting down.First 75 mg every other day to 50 mg every other day and then 50 mg every three days.At that point I would go as many days as I could possibly stand it before taking a 50 mg dose.The withdrawal symptoms were vertigo,confusion,and the "Brain zaps" that only someone who has gone thru this can actually relate to. I am finally done with this med although I still have some of the zaps now and again. Do not go on this drug unless you are willing to give up all feelings (good and bad) and are done with sex.I am now on hormone replacement therapy and feel great.I changed docs too becuase he thought Effexor was the wonder drug of the century and would not switch me to HRT.

column9: The  drug works well for my depression.  In 2008, I was laid off and eventually could not afford health insurance or medication. To go off Effexor XR is to dive into the black hole of insanity - confusion, depression, inability to reason (cook, pay bills, etc), 'brain zaps', suicidal thoughts and the belief that I would become homeless.  It was the scariest experience in my 20 years since diagnosis.  Fortunately I was able to get the drug from Wyeth and am again stable.  I do fear the next time I need to go off this drug for lack of funds or to change medications...just know that it will require medical intervention!

column2: roxy, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking Effexor XR about a year and a half ago to deal with a divorce.  It worked very very well.  I did experience some weight gain (about 10 lbs) and loss of interest in sex.  However, I still feel that if you need it you have to take it.  There's no point in suffering when there is something that can immediately help. After reading countless "caveats" about coming off it, I weaned myself off very slowly and with direction from my Dr. I reduced my dosage by 37.5mg 1 month at a time.  IT WORKED VERY VERY WELL.  I experienced little to no withdrawel symptoms.  I've been off the med for about 10 weeks.  Sadly I'm beginning to have more episodes of feeling depressed; not being able to get out of bed, having little-to-no energy, and am probably going to go back on it.  I really wanted to be "free and clear" of the med and I'm not sure that it's possible. Some people have a chemical imbalance and it's beyond their control.  Sadly I'm feeling that I'm one of those people...

column2: Jennifer  S., 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I Suffered from severe anxiety for years before I was prescribed Effexor XR-75mg once daily. It has changed my life and has worked wonders for me. column2: shivers, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was on Effexor XR 75 mg for about 5 years.  I suddenly began having a dizziness that was unexplained.  Emotionally, I felt good though, and thought maybe it was time to get off the drug.  I reduced my dosage down to 37.5 for two weeks, then cut the few remaining pills in half for about 10 days.  What ensued from there has been a nightmare.  I was having severe brain shivers most of the day every day for over two weeks.  Brain shivers are like an electrical stimulus to your brain.  My emotions and sensitivity to light and sound were severe.  My doctor was totally unavailable to me during this process.  It has now been over a month and all of these symptoms are still happening, although to a lesser degree.  However, I believe this is a VERY dangerous drug and would recommend against starting it.  If you are on it, try switching to something less severe and then titrate off.  There is no way of knowing the length of time I will have to suffer with these symptoms and apparently there is no relief from them.

column9: For 10 years, I took Effexor XR (300mg) for for a major depression and recently started to come off them. I suffer from Migraine's but since stop taking the medication, I get one every night combine with the shakes, chills and nausea. column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was on effexor for about 5 years for depression. Weening myself off of it was even worse, with those side effects amplified times ten. I also developed a severe anxiety disorder after coming off it 2 years ago that I have been struggling with ever since. Effexor's website says it is perfectly safe and not addictive. THIS IS A LIE. I regret ever taking Effexor, and I wish I did more research before taking it.

column2: 25-34 Female  (Patient)
column9: i have taken effexor xr regularly for over 5 years.  the side effects of going off of it (missing from one dose to several) are so severe i get anxiety just thinking about it.  i recently went off of it suddenly and the withdrawal symptoms ranged from the most severe nausea I've ever experienced (including vomiting) to hyper-sensitivity through my fingers to a brain-clicking feeling like a cd that keeps skipping to anxiety and emotional upheaval.  the side effects lasted about 2 weeks and I've decided not to take the medication anymore because i don't EVER want to have to experience them again. ever.

column9: I have been taking Effexor entering into six years.  My prior experiences with anti-depressants has not been positive (dramatic mood changes), but with Effexor I am "even". column2: montanaguy, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: At first I thought this may have been helping my depression, but it is so difficult to tell. The doc gave me 37.5 mg pills to take for 2 weeks to taper off, and now I have been on zero Effexor for one week.. and I have major ringing in the ears, nausea, dizziness, shaking, constantly tired, can't sleep, and bizzare crying jags over little things that never bothered me before.  I am hoping that this will all subside within the next week or so.  I have to agree that the benefits of Effexor are not worth the withdrawal symptoms.  I hope and pray they are over soon.

column2: pamelaapeters, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Low-dose (75mg. daily) Effexor XR has not alleviated symptoms of menopause exacerbated by use of Tamoxifen following early stage breast cancer surgery and radiation. Furthermore, I am experiencing disquieting symptoms called "brain zaps" if a dose is missed, delayed and as I attempt to taper-off the drug.  Prescribing doctors seem mostly unfamiliar with these symptoms but internet reports of the withdrawal issues are common and need to be investigated.  Are these mini-seizures?  Controlled research needs to be undertaken with scientifically based recommendations following for those of us experiencing "brain zaps" that cause momentary disorientation.  Perhaps we need an investigation into this by FDA or a watchdog group to determine what the manufacturer knows, when they had the information and what is being done to protect the public!

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
R.D., 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I am 24,  and I started taking Effexor XR 3 months after my daughter was born. My Dr. said I was suffering from postpartum depression. I have never taken any medication, besides the Effexor. It helped with the anxiety. But the depression didnt go away. I was on 37.5 for 5 months and went to 75 until recently. I am now tapering off, per Dr.'s orders. I feel like I am going to go into shock. I am so dizzy and sick that I cant even drive. And I am very grouchy. I have no idea how long this will last. My Dr. 'promised' it would not be this way. Another lie from a Dr. If you are considering this drug, please choose something with better withdrawl effects. This is soo not worth the little help it gives.

column2: BlueCatLover, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I've found that over the 10 years I've been taking Effexor XR (150MG) that I have become more irritable, have trouble sleeping, and have had an increase with ADD.  I fly off the handle quite a bit. My husband would describe me as "hyper" a lot of the time.  I tried weaning off of this drug while increasing a new med - Wellbutrin - at the recommendation of my doctor.  The withdrawal from the effexor, once I was completely off of it - was HORRIBLE!  Brain zaps, dizziness, night terrors (even when taking an afternoon nap) - oh, and very very tired - I started just curling up on the bed and falling asleep once I was off of the Effexor. The Wellbutrin gave me serious stomach problems, so this doc said "I don't want you taking anything (meaning anti-depressents) until we know what's going on with you."  Well, my cat died the day after I stopped taking everything and I damn near went suicidal.  I mean I went completely beserk, had crying jags, etc.  Got back on EffexorXR (37.5 mg) immediately per my primary care physician's insistence. I have since found new medication psychiatrist who suggested that maybe the Effexor's effect on my norephinephrine was just too much for me.  At least at my current low Effexor dose 37.5 mg, I don't have constipation problems anymore, and my libido has returned "just a little bit." (thank goodness).  I'm ramping up on Zoloft again (per doc's suggestion) - it did wonders for me when I first started taking in in 1994-2006 (and I lost weight, too) so maybe it will help me again.  I sure need something to pull me out of my current depression.  But the Effexor WITHDRAWAL effects ARE HORRIBLE - and I'm a little bit scared of going completely off of it for that reason.

column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: At first this seemed like a miracle drug. It gave me lots of energy, made me very happy and optimistic, controlled my appetite, and even seemed to help my fibro pain! I experienced: tremors, fainting, loss if coordination, insomnia, blurred vision, peeling rash around my mouth, racing heart, irregular heart beat, & shortness of breath among some other things. I went off cold turkey and the withdrawls were awful but I needed to get off it quickly. It was very disappointing since it was working better than any other anti depressant I'd been on...

column2: ECAS, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

column2: Mona, Colorado, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started Effexor XR a little over 3 months ago for night sweats (menopause). I take about 1 hour before bed each night. It has worked wonderfully for me.  I have missed an occasional dose with no problem.  Started out at 37.5mg for 1 month, now at the 75mg level. The night sweats have all but stopped, which allows me to get a restful nights sleep.  It has made a tremendous difference overall, I'm back to my happy, positive self.  I feel like the old me before menopause began.  My husband & I can cuddle again without me having to pull away due to hot flashes!I also was experiencing increased migraines before Effexor which I suspect was largely due to lack of sleep (and hormone flux because of menopause).  These too have been less frequent.  I have not noticed any weight gain with this product and I found I have lots and lots of energy again.  After reading the other reviews regarding addiction, I do intend to speak to my doctor about going back down to the 37.5mg level.  Even that level made a big difference in the night sweats.  I am not a proponent of taking pills for everything, but believe me I tried all the 'natural' remedies with no success.

column2: Mimi0704, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor is the only antidepressant I've used but it helped me immediately. You must take it at the same time of day (i take it after dinner)everyday to avoid drenching NIGHT SWEATS,headache and feeling like crying. I noticed WEIGHT GAIN of about 10 pounds over the last 2 years. Too bad it's so expensive.

column2: SideEffex82, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was on Effexor XR for 8 years for depression/mild anxiety through the end of high school and through college. I had been on various dosages of Prozac, Zoloft, Paxil with either poor side effects (inability to orgasm) or poor effectiveness. Doc put me on 150mg of Effexor XR. It helped my depression, anxiety and libido but the side effects and withdrawl were horrible and TOTALLY debilitating! I was getting my prescriptions through MedCo's mail order system so it was very easy to be out of meds and at least 3 days from getting any more. The worst withdrawl symptom was a nauseous dizzy feeling in my head. I could not move around without feeling as though my brain were somewhat disconnected from my head. It would worsen with each day to the point of nearly vomiting! Let me be very clear here, I could not move my body without feeling like I was going to barf! And I have an iron stomach! Another serious effect that I have experienced is hand tremors. It has been 12 years since I began taking Effexor XR and 4 years since I stopped and my hands still shake, sometimes so bad that people ask me if I have Parkinson's Disease!! Most of the time people say nothing but look at me like I am a junkie! I have been to the Doc and they ran tests and have no explanation- even though I KNOW that I never had this problem until I went on Effexor XR. I would recommend this pill because it helped me overcome a severe depression but I caution strongly against it if you have a hard time keeping a pill schedule. The Doc's didn't want me to go off of the pill. They said depression was "in my genes" and I would fight it my whole life. Well, as a biologist, let me tell you that THAT is NOT always the case. I have been anti-depressant free for 4 years and I have never felt more clear, fresh, raw and happy than I do now. Sure there are bummers, sometimes every day. But I just focus on the good parts and count my blessings with my shakey fingers every moment I remember to!

Brdoon, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Taking huge amounts of narcotics daily which were prescribed for me, I began to get suicidal , anxiety and depression. Lexapro was not helping ..maybe making it worse (according to a Federal study) I was on Lexapro...but my income decreased so I needed a generic. My shrink put me on generic Effexor. I did not know why immediately but my GI doctor figured out why I was getting nausea...it was due to effexor...he is a smart guy. After a few weeks the side effects passed.I no longer have highs or lows but can function without fear and anxiety. Unfortunately I am still falling victim to spells of obsessive thinking and acting on these after awhile. I do not have the daily OCD,...the trembling hand washing etc but get fixated on things or a course of action contrary to all the best advice. It has caused me problems and cost me money in the real world...plus a lot of humiliation. Being aware of my lack of awareness when I am in a spell causes me suicidal thoughts...probably just self-pity but I am an adult and soemtimes cannot find real reasons to live...on the contrary I find more reasons to be dead. I attend 12 step meetings however and have listened to folks like me who after years realized their life had completely turned around until they were "happy, joyous and free". I also hear at these meetings about the ones who self-destructed, either immediately thru suicide or slowly thru alcohol and drugs. I do not think God wants me to kill myself but I do wish he would fast-track my spiritual emotional, mental, physical, situational and locational recovery.Effexor okay but Lexapro made me feell better and Celexa really helped me  fast when I went into severe depression. I would like to be completely drug-free but do not want to be the same person I was. Have not put on any weight but it is hard to tell about side effects because I take other drugs as well.

column2: Blue Collar, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: An absolute godsend for me. After having lived a life barraged with social anxiety disorder coupled with depression, I had finelly gotten to the point of going to my doctor and asking for help. The best way I could express my condition to him, was by saying,"Something's wrong." I was loaded with self-doubt, could not make ANY decisions with a measure of confidence, had paranoid thoughts on a near daily basis, and suffered from enormously heavy feelings of guilt (reliving bad scenes & bad decisions I've made  in my lifetime.) Was started on 75 mgs. or Effexor XR five months ago. My life changed instantly!! It helped with the anxiety within a couple of hours, and all the irrational negative thinking has subsided.Downsides are involved though. For me, there were two.And they were major for me. Libido prblems and extreme tiredness. Both issues have been minimalized through pinpointing MY correct doseage, and my body adapting to the medication. After topping-out at 225mgs.(way too much for me) I have zeroed in on my proper dose; maintaining the wonderful effectiveness of the medication, and nearly ridding myself of the unpleasant side effects. I say nearly because they are still there... however, they are very slight. Also, I did wean myself off completely back in Nov. and DID NOT have any of the horribles effects I am reading about on here. I DID however experience "my old self" immediately! Needless to say, I restarted the medication and am having huge success on the smallest doseage of 37.5 mgs. per day. This is enough for me, and I have a Keith Richards' like constitution!! That being said, I am amazed that such a low level dose has affected my life in such a miraculous way!!!

However, I found myself turning into a zombie and went off cold turkey - very big mistake. My doctor was able to eventually wean me off of it over a 3 week period of time and am doing much better on Welbutrin.

column2: danielle3244, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I had been suffering from severe anxiety and depression for most of my life.  My therapist felt I had come to a "wall" and may need medication to help me overcome whatever left over anxiety and depression I had.  I was put on LEXAPRO first, that was okay, just made me EXHAUSTED !  He then switched me to effexor XR, the lower dosage of 30 something at first, then currently I take 75mg.  This drug has been a NIGHTMARE!  I didn't realize what a mistake trying to take myself off the drug would be.  I have SEVERE vertigo, nausea, ringing in my head, nightmares, night sweats, my heart beats uncontrollably- I would NEVER have started this drug if I had realized what awful withdrawal symptoms I would face- calling the doctor tomorrow, seeing what I can do to help me get off of it.  I have been trying 'cold turkey' for a couple days and it is absolute torture. I don't reccomend this drug AT ALL !

column2: maria s, 55-64 on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I took this drug for 11 months on the advise of my therapist.  It did assist in relief of depression and addiction but the side effects were unacceptable. I felt like I didn't recognize the person I had become.  Came down gradually and had some discomfort but am so glad I did.  Now more than a year since discontinuing treatment, still have "zaps" occasionally and have never been able to cry to release emotions.  Regret ever having taken this treatment.

column2: gabz666, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: i've been dx with MDD since my teens, (first offical dx @ 16). i have intense episodes of depression every 6months pretty much. ive tried celexa, which made me feel high and then low so i stopped taking that. now i am taking effexor xr and the first week i felt really high and was really excited that finally i might be coming out of this depression. i was suicidal, cutting, angry, aggressive, anxious, having panic attacks, crushing guilt, a big mood swinging mess. so i thought it was working. now a little over a month in and at 150mg i feel nothing. it has helped with the agression and constant worrying. but i still have bad anxiety attacks, agoraphobic(w/o the help of an benzo) which my doc doesnt want to rx me, and i still have crying spells. i have no sex drive, which was actually quite healthy to begin with. i am more prone to an agitated depression, and the effexor has changed it to a lethargic depression. where now, i dont want to do anything, and i dont care to do anything, when i am actually the type that wants to do everything and cares too much. i stopped taking it a few days ago and have experience a weird feeling. i feel detached and have flown back into the psychotic mood changes, yelling at the drop of a hat, if something is not in order. so i suppose i will start taking it again. ive told my doc and i will be seeing him soon for some help. not sure what he will do, up the dose more? or an add on?

column2: lunytaz, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: This medication has been helpful in helping to control depression and anxiety.  However, if you are considering this medciation, you should be aware that it is very important not to miss a dose.  It causes a very uneasy/uncomfortable feeling...kind of like a hangover, but light-headed and dizzy.  Even being a little late taking it can cause these symptoms so you should get in the habit of taking it at the same time every day.  Another thing to be careful of...don't stand or raise up to quickly or you can become very light headed

I hate to sound so picky but my eyes are greenish-hazel so if my pupils dialated, it was really obvious and I felt really self-consious about it. I'm taking about like my pupils were almost as big as my eye. I thought people might think i was on some illegal drugs, so I just decided to go off the meds. WOW, major withdrawl symptoms. It's hard to say, if I had dark colored eyes, I would def stay with this med. I hadn't felt so good in a long time, and it worked awesome for both depression and anxiety! Will try Lexapro next

column2: trickykitty, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Effexor for about eight yrs. and it is one of the most effective meds I have ever been on.  I was without it for a few months from an insurance problem and had to go off cold turkey and I will say that it was terrible for the withdrawal, though nothing as bad as the horror stories I have read from other people.  The biggest problem for me was not the withdrawal however, it was that nothing else that I tried worked for me.  I wound up fixing the problem with the insurance and went back on it.  Even knowing what the withdrawal entails, if the benefit outweighs the risk... that's the basis for all meds.  My experience with this med has been a lot more positive than the stories I have read. Regardless if people say that it's addictive and regardless if I ever wind up having to go through the withdrawals again if my insurance drops coverage again... this is an essential med for me and I will take advantage of the benefits it brings for as long as I am able to.  Without it I am a crying miserable wreck and completely overwhelmed by my depression.  With it there are still depression factors but at a level I can live with.  I do take four other psych meds along with the effexor and my current dose is 150mg/day.  Just for reference, the other meds are buspar, klonopin, seroquel and lamictal.  No benefit from trials of prozac, wellbutrin or celexa.

column2: Lou, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Caregiver)
column9: I left my wife of 15 years a year after she started taking 300MG per day of effexor. Up untill she took effexor and when she was on prozac our friends and family thought of us as love birds. We had a great sex life and that completely disappeared withing the first two months. She became angry, impulsive, agitated towards me and the rest of the family. She thinks it is working. She tells her shrink that it is working. She sees her shrink for 30 minutes every 3 months and he renews her prescription without checking for side effects with her family. If you are thinking of taking this drug, give yourself a going away party because you will be leaving everyone who knows and loves you you will be replaced by an entirely different personality. Here is how Weyth promoted this drug through falsified testing and paying for positive reports from the New York Times and the Wall Street Journal http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/17/health/17depres s.html http://www.nybooks.com/articles/22237 http://blogs.wsj.com/health/2008/12/18/dear-me-ne meroff-wrote-himself-about-payment-for-effexor-ar ticle/ This medication is addictive! Addiction - Big Pharma marketing calls it " discontinuation syndrome" which the shrinks don't tell you about before you start taking it. Agitation, anger, impulsiveness, memory loss, loss of cognative ability and weight gain. The manufacturer stresses the opposite - weight loss - but that is true in young women. It makes it appear that women are getting a feel good pill and a diet pill, when in fact many post menopausal women gain 30 - 50 pounds. Pfizer/Weyeth deserve an army of tort lawyers. Hippocrates oath has been changed from "first do no harm" to "first line you pockets with cash."

column2: Nearly Normal, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: It took many, many years of trial and error before Effexor XR became available.  I have taken it for a number of years now. I was recently offered the opportunity to try a different medication, but I'm not risking it.  Effexor XR has been a life saver for me. column2: jellytwine, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been on effexor for 7 months and the dosage is 225mg once a day. I ran into a complication with getting my script renewed and had to go without it for a few days. I went through the worst withdrawals ever. I have gone through withdrawals from a severe addiction to a very strong illegal drug and THAT wasn't even this bad! It caused vertigo as well as horrible sweating, nausea, abdominal pain, eye pain from the light, and the worst mood swings ever! My husband had to take me to the ER because he found me on the kitchen floor and all the chairs were knocked over, apparently I had fallen. I couldn't remember anything at all until an hour after I had taken a dose of the effexor which the doctor had given me. Also.  Since I have been on the effexor, I have become an anti-social zombie. I barely get out of bed and my already lack of motivation turned into a lack of life period. The only thing I like about this medication is the fact that it stabilizes my mood, well... more like it keeps me mono-toned 100% of the time. I no longer have extreme lows or highs.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed 10 years ago with severe depression. The standard course of treatment was prescribed, therapy and drugs. After two years of meds and less than satisfactory results Effexor got its turn. Finally, I had relief, for a few months. Effectiveness tapered off, dosage increased, then combination with other meds. Sound familiar, after 10 years enough of this. The treatment is worse than the illness. My answer is healing prayer and neurofeedback therapy. Get off the chemical highway, it wont cure and is endless.

column2: helpguyy, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: After 9 months on Effexor XR I feel confident to say this drug has completely and utterly changed my life.  I read many reviews before starting the drug, and I was scared to death of all the reviews that said the drug had horrendous side effects, and was absolutely impossible to get off of.  Well, I have experienced just about every side effect imaginable, that I will outline below for you.  But, I will never experience the effects of withdrawing from the drug, because I have absolutely no intention of getting off the drug.  My life is now phenomenally enjoyable, which I will also outline below.  I'm going to give you complete details, because I wish someone had maybe done the same about a year ago when I was searching desperately for answers to my many questions.  Here goes. ME: I am a forty-something male, married, two sporty kids.  Profession requires public speaking and frequent client interaction.  I was a professsional athlete and continue to work out almost every day.  PROBLEM: I've always been extremely anxious around people, although few people knew it.  It was a constant struggle being around people other than those I knew really well.  I was also nervous talking to important clients or making important presentations, but, again hid it.  The reality, though, was I was not enjoying myself, avoided all such situations, and therefore didn't excel at many things I did, despite the fact that I am a very smart, witty and caring person (don't mean to sound vain - just saying I've always had the tools to be an extremely successful person, but my anxiety/depression squelched everything).  My anxiety occassionally elevated to full blown panic attacks where it was obvious to the people I was with that I was nervous.  I know now that I was experiencing related depression as well. At times I would get into a complete funk, tired and exhausted, despite the fact I was getting lots of sleep.   I would be in a fog. CURE: My GP prescribed ativan at first, since my primary c

column2: belch, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: well pleased with results re: depression;learning to live with reduced libido...

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I began taking effexor xr 37.5 mg about 4 years ago. I had started taking prozac about 6 months after my daughter was born, stayed on that about 1 year but experienced weight gain, stayed sleepy. went off that about a year, then started having anxiety again, crying at the drop of a hat. My doc recommended effexor.  I asked to stay on lowest possible dose, and have really liked this mecication.  the only side effects I noticed when I 1st started were extreme "energy" esp. when I 1st woke up, and some trouble sleeping, but I was already having trouble with that. That subsided quickly enough, the only other thing that was significant was headaches, but I can't say for sure that it was from med.  They have stopped too. I feel effexor has allowed me to be the person I'm meant to be.  I feel very happy and "normal" again, even better that ever.  The few side effects I have/had were not enough for me to stop taking it.  A co-worker quit her effexor cold turkey and told me " you've got to get off that stuff" story similar to other posts here.  My take is--don't stop any meds like that cold turkey, that's just dumb.  And everyone is different, but I would stay on as low a dose as possible, I think It makes it easier if you do decide to stop.  I wish I didn't have to take anything, but since I do, I like this med.  With prozac I felt sluggish, and was ravenous all the time, but not with this.  I feel very energetic most of the time, and don't worry like I used to.  But there are alot of meds out there, try something different if one doesn't do it for you.

column2: eleanor.stevens@insightbb.com,  Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I've been taking this drug for over 20 yrs. for depression, I believe it helps, lately, however, I'm not sure it is still effective

column2: Steph, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on Effexor XR for about 10 years now. I tried other drugs, but they didn't work or made me really ill. I also have problems with severe anxiety and this has really helped! I can always tell if I've forgotten to take it though, and I have read the other comments about coming off of it. If I miss a day I get nauseated and woosie. It has caused me to have high blood pressure, but, when I think of how much better I feel and how it helps the anxiety, well, I guess it's worth it.

column2: triplet mom, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I started taking this drug for severe chronic depression and anxiety. Beginning this drug, I was vomiting right away, so make sure you take it with food. The side effects get better as you continue taking it, and rather quickly. After taking this drug for 2 months though, the drug was helping immensley with the anxiety, but making my depression much worse! I began hallucinating and hearing voices & whispers, and became very suicidal. I slept alot, had zero energy or desire to do anything. I wouldn't shower for days and couldn't even get basic things done. I am now weaning off of it to start something new (Celexa), and the weaning has been fine except that I notice that I am much more aggitated and irritable, and anger very quickly. Anxiety attacks are coming back as well. I have back problems, so I also take muscle relaxers, pain killers, and nerve relaxers as well. Not sure if there is an interaction going on? It's very hard to be patient with finding a drug to work for you. I am half tempted to try the medical marijuana to see if that helps with pain and anxiety?

column2: Leigh, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I'm on the generic form of Effexor Xr, and it works wonderfully for my depression, but my doctor put me on it for anxiety. It doesn't work for anxiety at all. It seems as it actually got worse. The first time I was on it, I had dry mouth and appetite loss. This is the 2nd time I have been on it and at 150 mg per day, I have not noticed any side effects. It's a good depression medication but not so much for anxiety.

column2: tbrown, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had very good results with this medication.

column2: cw, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: i researched this ahead of time and it was described as an anti-depressant/anti-anxiety drug. a bell went off.  it sounded like something that might work for me as i have chronic life-long depression, but there was also that edge of anxiety.  i started taking effexor/xr around 10 years ago (75 mg. 3 times a day) and i have to say that out of all the medications i have taken, this is one where i could actually feel an improvement of my anxiety symptoms in particular.  i still also take other anti-depressants and will need to pretty much for the rest of my life.  i would recommend trying effexor if you have or currently do take medications but still feel like there's just something still not quite right about the way you feel and would like to try something new.  i'm pretty sure you could add this to whatever you're taking (which is what i did), but your doctor would of course make that decision.  good luck to all of you who suffer from depression.

column2: Billy BUBB, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been around the block as far as anti-depressants go- nardil, amitriptoline, asendin, and several others, including tri-cyclics.  Was on Prozac later, then Lexapro.  With Lexapro, I felt a lot better as far as moods and swings went, but after taking it for 4 years, it leveled off and worked less and less.  Then I took Effexor.  I feel a lot better, and more level mood wise.  I've been suicidal since age 14, and am now 54.  I've gotten past the pain part, so 'leaving town' isn't the issue it once would have been.  IOW, it'd be a whole lot easier to do myself in now than before, were it not for wife and kids who would take it as something their fault.I liked Lexapro, but it stopped working out.  Effexor works, but all the posts and comments are scaring me.  What to do?  stop and die, or keep taking it and die, or at least deal with powerful side effects, while the other part of effexor allows a better life for the time being.  A pill for every need- medical legacy of the USA.  Just a wholly BIZARRE plight to be in.  Here I thought that other stuff I was experiencing was some other pill. sweating, lucid dreams, strange physical sensations, 'blank spots' during the course of the day or workday, strange physical pains or feelings.  Maybe back to Lexapro.Thank you all for posting, for your experiences have led me to think about other realms that had not occurred to me...  Just so bizarre!  And yeah, even the sex dept has gone south

column2: jennarms, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: The only time I thought it was working for me was in the 2nd to 4th months. After that I thought that it had "quit-working". column9: I have been on ex for over 7 yrs now. It's hard to remember how or if it was effective in the beginning. I have been batteling SEVERE depression for over 10 yrs and spent 5 of those yrs in bed. I've been on all kinds of meds in different combos and ultimately came off everything 2 yrs ago except for the effexor. I CANT stOP. If I go even 2 days without it the brain zaps are terrible. Fortunately I don't seem to be having any of the other side effects many of you have talked about ie no wt gain or moodiness that I can see but how do you differentiate the moodiness of the med effect from the symptoms of the depression itself? If I really knew that ex was still helping me I wouldn't mind it so much but I just don't know if it really is helping or if I'm staying on it to avoid the withdrawl of stopping. Also I don't have insurence and it's expensive to stay on it just to stop the withdrawl. Still I have found that most other meds I have tried have had worse side effects. Maybe I'm just really sensitive to meds now that I have tried so many but with some meds I would forget what I was saying half way through a sentence. It was awful. If I try again to get off ex I would do it over a 1 yr period. I don't know what to do. I'm still classified as severly depressed but at least I'm working and interacting with people again. column9: For chronic depression, I see a psychiatrist, who prescribed Effexor XR in combination Wellbutrin along w/counselling. Yes, I have side effects--mild sweatiness, loss of apetite, the need to be busy and enjoying semi-solitude. Every once in a the combination "fails" and I start down the "slippery slope". I have successfullybeen weaned off Effexor under the therapist's guidance and I never experienced the brain pain that other reviewers felt. Truthfully, I'd rather have the side effects than be in bed in a fetal position OR WORSE. I have accepted I will have to be on Effexor XR for the rest of my life. column2: jodyjean0821, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I left a post a few months back describing my experience with Effexor XR.  I decided to wean myself off this drug as I experienced weight gain & SEVERE withdrawl symptoms.  I have been tapered down to the 37.5 mg level (I had been up to 300mg) but I can not quit the drug completely!!!  Even at this low dose, I experience the extreme effects I did when I forgot my medication while on vacation.  One side effect I did not realize I had was a complete lack of interest in sex!  Now that I am down to the lower dose, my sex drive is back thankfully & my energy has increased.  I have lost 15 pounds due to diet & exercise since lowering my dose.  My advice to others is STILL the same!!  DO NOT accept this drug from anyone, even a doctor!!  Since I have been unable to remove myself completely from this drug, my opinion about this is even stronger. There are so many alternatives, do yourself a favor & JUST SAY NO!!!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I began taking this med in '08 after trying lexapro and wellbutrin, which did not work for me. I took 75 mg once a day (effexor xr). AFter one week I immediate felt relief and felt like my depression was being treated! I felt wired at first, dry mouth, nausea...the side effects it states you will have. But they eventually went away. I stayed on this med for 6mths, but since I planned to have a baby, I went off of it. The only withdrawal symptmos I had were the brain zaps, but I gradually withdrew the amount I was taking by breaking open the capsule. I only had to do this for 2 weeks. Now after having the baby, I am on this med again...this time on the generic form. Same initial symptoms. I have been taking it for 3 weeks now and I already feel like my head is clearer and I'm not as angry. I think with these types of medicines you have to just try to see if they do work for you or not. Just b/c someone else had awful reactions or withdrawals does not mean you will! With any of these drugs that affect you physiological system, you do risk that possibility of withdrawal symptoms!

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I did not take Effexor XR very long because it hospitalized me with SEVERE DEPRESSION and SUICIDAL THOUGHTS at a very low dose. I realize that I just had a very bad reaction to this drug, but it was the worst reaction I have had from any of the medications I have been on for Bipolar Depression (close to 15). I now take Cymbalta, which is also a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, and it has been one of the best medications I have ever been on. My advice for anyone who is considering taking Effexor XR is to look out for a severe reaction involving depression and suicidal thoughts. I wasn't sure if my reaction was to Effexor XR or another new drug I was taking, but it turned out to be Effexor XR. I thought I could just tough it out through the side effects and that it would maybe get better, but that was a horrible mistake that put me in the hospital.  Just be sure to use caution when starting this medication!

column2: tomboy, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)

column2: keray55, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been living with anxiety for my entire life and finally decided that no amount of therapy would help and it was time to medicate.  My doctor prescribed XR as it was the latest and greatest drug out there.  Initially it worked wonders.  For the first time I could breathe freely everyday, I was productive, and never nervous.  A few years in I decided this wasnt something that I wanted to take forever, especially since my MD warned me it wasnt for long term use and it should have changed my chemistry.  I weaned myself off, which I expected to be painful based on others experiences, and it was.  That wasnt the worst part though.  After withdrawal ended I was left feeling like I had no brain.  Years later I still feel the same way.  I have no memory, I'm always at a loss for words, and I can't begin to articulate my thoughts.  Effexor changed my life for the good for a very small amount of time, but the damage it has done has been much much worse.  I can only hope its not permanent.  Be very careful when taking this drug.  Think long and hard about the side effects, because there will be some, and what you would do if it fundamentally changed you if you decided to stop taking it.

Within one week I had serious thoughts of suicide...did not actually attempt but the desire was very strong.Now I feel like a prisoner to this medication. I experience erratic mood swings, paranoia, apathy, no sex drive, jitters. My body/brain won't let me sleep until very late at night, so I'm always tired and lethargic.I was once an outgoing person, and now i'm reclusive and anti-social.I believe Effexor is a great short term solution to combat depression and potpartum. I wish I would have known about the side effects of long term use because I do feel it was a factor in my divorce.

column2: Crocodile1, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor XR is not effective until you get to the 150mg threshold.  It is FDA approved up to 225mg/day, but many doctors prescribe way higher than this with good results.  I saw one post on here where the person said the drug didn't work and they were at 37.5mg/day.  Yes, the drug will have virtually no effect on you at that low dosage!!I've been on it a year and I'm at 300mg/day.  It is a wonderful medicine, but I don't like the sweating and the fact that it raises blood pressure.  People, DO NOT trust your primary care or family doctor to know about these psychoactive drugs.  They mean well, but a Psychiatrist is where you need to go for the guys who know everything about psychoactive drugs.  Also, I am not a doctor, nor do I work for a drug company.  I just wanted to throw some facts out there for people to use so that they can be helped.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I took Effexor 150 (mg) for three years.  Missed a dose, here and there, and the withdrawal was intense.  The electric shock feeling was terrifying the first time. I complained to my doctor ans was told that the "shock" feeling might actually be a plummet in saratonin levels.  So, on my own, I cut back, first to 75mg per day and then half again.  I was able to go dose free for 2-3 days before the "shock" would come and I'd take a pill.  I continued just treating the "shocks" as they came until I was pill free for days, then weeks at a time.  If you are ready to wean off Effexor, get your doctor to lower and break up your dosage (instead of 2x75mg per day, ask for 4x32.5). This will help you begin slowly skipping one dose and so on.  Effexor is a fantastic medication and it doesn't have to be a nightmare (literally) to come off it.  Pay attention to your "shocks" or crashes as you lower your dosage and treat only when you feel them.  It will work.  I was completely off the medication within three months and I had very little hardship.

column2: ACPants, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I first began this drug as an alternative to taking stimulants/ssris in combination therapy for adhd and depression. My depression was under control within 2 months, but my dose had to go higher as I was experiencing withdrawl even when taking the drug. It does not help my adhd and has even been antagonistic to my impulsivity and restlessness. Once I became comfortable on it, at 28, we found out that I have severe secondary hypertension and might have a stroke if I stay on Effexor. I'm in the process of weaning to Cymbalta with the option of going back on a stimulant now, and I feel better already. Know that this drug is definitely a lifer, and it does help control depression and anxiety very well, but to keep an eye on your blood pressure, pay strict attention to your diet, and excercise, even if you don't have the motivation or energy. That's what saved my life.

column2: revdon, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking medications for ADD (no hyperactivity) for over 25 years. My ADD symptoms were a strong tendency to "spin off" into depression when facing manageable but tough problems. And also when I was exhausted by overwork! The depression became bad enough at 26 to cause me to take a year off from everything. I've been on many, many drugs; most worked for a while, some never worked, but none were too bad as far as side effects. After Prozac "pooped out" on me, I was put on Effexor, 75 mg twice a day at first, then building up to 300 mg XR once a day. The med seemed to work great the first several months. But then my energy dropped, which led me to cut back exercising. Over the next couple of years, I gained 80 pounds! After batteries of tests and numerous nutritional/diet solutions, I peaked out at about 280 pounds. I'm 5' 7" tall! My doctors concluded my weight gain was due to the Effexor. SO I got off - but OH GOD was it bad! It took nearly a month for the drug to "clear" my system. During that time (and especially the first two weeks), I had shakes, tremors, problems sleeping. Worse, there was this strange effect: my head felt like it was being whirled around, quickly, like you might experience on an amusement park ride. And I would get what others have described as "brain zaps" - it felt like I was getting a sudden surge of electricity through my brain (without pain). My Psych put me on Wellbutrin after the first two weeks. That got some of my energy back, and improved my mood. At the end of a month, all the weirdness stopped. The Wellbutrin helped me to feel more like myself. This drug is effective up front - but I'm convinced it should be used temporarily for severe cases. Then a patient can switch off to another med once things are more "under control."

column2: jodyjean0821, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Effexor XR for almost 2 years now & have made the decision to try to wean myself off this drug, mainly because of the weight gain I experienced while taking it.  I also had a horrible experience where I went on vacation & forgot my medication.  The withdrawl symptoms started the next day.  I was completely floored by what happened to me; the dizziness, sweating, headache, brain zaps & lack of ability to concentrate were severe.  I was also completely drained of energy.  I have been on a lower dose for about a week now, and none of the side effects, just a lingering tiredness.  So far, so good.  I would urge all patients to seek treatment other than Effexor & tell doctors that if they feel they MUST prescribe it, to let the patient in on the symptoms they will experience when they get off the drug, or even miss a dose.  Im sure if I would have known the problems associated with Effexor XR, I would have NEVER, EVER taken this drug.  I would suggest everyone else to do the same.

column9: This drug worked well for my anxiety, but I got nervous after reading the postings about the withdrawal symptoms.  I am back to post that my w/d was FINE. column2: more to life, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This is a miracle drug,However if I had it to do all over I would have never started this drug to begin with. Like I said it was a miracle my anxiety went away I was able to deal with every day events more efectively.But before I knew it it controlled my actions I was no longer able to cry,enjoy sex,have impathy,or concern for most anything in my life.It made me numb to most all things.And after 4 years of being numb I decided I was going to gain controll of my life again little did I know it would be more hell than the reason I started taking this drug. It's been 1 year now And I'm down to 1/2 of a 37.5  pill a week,down from 225 a day. If I had of known that this loss of controll of my own life  is what it would have done to  me I would have put this effort into finding a support group or some other form of non drug related help. Life may have been difficult but I had feelings, Happiness saddness and love I wasn't numb.Life is getting better with time,The side effects are leaving day by day and I cried for the first time in 5 years.(tears of joy)It was better than any drug getting me through life.So please research this drug find people who are taking it or who have taken it before you decide.It is a miracle drug but it is also the drug from HELL.Good luck

column9: I gained 30 pounds on Effexor. After stopping the drug it took me over 12 months to reduce the weight gain. It slows the body's ability to metabolize food and the effects are residual after discontinued use. It works for anxiety but has a terrible weight gain side effect.

column2: RLS96, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had severe post partum depression after the birth of my son. I tried just about everything, nothing worked but effexor.  Side effects were mainly sleep disturbances, I had very vivid dreams and always woke up exhausted.  I had to get off this medication when I got pregnant with my daughter after being on it for two years.  HELL, utter HELL.  The withdraws were horrific, I was paranoid, suicidal, delusional, and I am lucky I had a great support network.  I chose not to start taking it again after the birth of my daughter and have done fine.  If I ever had to take it again, the only way I would is if I knew I could take it for the rest of my life.

column2: unknown, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I had only been on this drug for 1  and a half years...too long!!! It worked really well, it did, but now that i am trying to get off of it I want to die! I have serious anxiety around vomiting and nausea and they are the number 1 and 2 withdrawal symptoms!! Its been 8 days without the drug and I still have a hard time concentrating, I can't move quickly or I'll become nauseous, I dry heave in the morning or sometimes randomly, I am SO FREAKIN HOT and I can't cool down, I sleep all day (even at work - thank goodness for a wellness room), I've got muscle spasms, "brain zaps" where its like the world does a shuffle inside my skull...DO NOT GO ON THIS DRUG UNLESS YOU HAVE SERIOUSLY DEEP, DEEP DEPRESSION. There are much better options out there. I have been on 6 other medications, this one working the best for "moods" but I had no libido and was more or less numb for the entire time and the withdrawal is not even remotely worth it. It almost negates anything good Effexor ever did for me. If given a choice, I'd go back to Wellbutrin. That said, I've opted out of the antidepressant route all together and am going to a Naturopath and dealing with my issues through CBT (cognitive behavioural therapy). Please really consider your reasons for needing to be on medication and how long you think you may be on it. Effexor, if it has to be used, should only be as a very last resort. VERY LAST - it is like withdrawing from heroine, and i was on the absolute lowest prescibable dosage!!

column2: Stephen, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed Effexor a few years back after suffering a nervous breakdown and self-haming.I was initially put on Seroxat bt it had little effect.I found Effexor worked well to relieve depression and anxiety but sometimes it worked too well and I would feel  mildly euphoric but never manic or out of control.I think that it may be a mildly addictive drug.As regards coming off the drug,what I remember most were the "brain zapping" jolts, like an electric current flashing through your head.These passed quickly but are unpleasant.Side effects: Sweating,teeth-grinding,mild euphoria,intermittent libido, problems with sleeping.I'm back on the drug again now and Iknow whn to cut down on the strength/frequency of the dosage when I feel high after a couple of days.Overall, it helped me when I was in a very poor mental state but remember:The drug is going to affect everyone in their own way.Make your own decision, Talk to your doctor and READ THE BLOODY LABEL before taking this, or any, drug.The Internet means that there is little excuse for ignorance,but exercise caution.Best of luck to you sll and the drug is only a part of recovery.

column2: glenn57377, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have had problems with depression and anxiety since experiencing severe stress related to a bad marriage, extremely stressful job, going to college part-time and raising my son........all at the same time.....starting in 1996.  I went through a lot of doctors, therapists, group and medicine to get to the normal state I am in today.  One out of the five therapists I experienced was effective.  Group, for me, was useless.  I take 225 mg of Effexor XR once a day and a light dose of Klonopin twice a day.  That, combined with putting my foot down and taking charge of my life made all the difference.  I am a very happy, in charge, successful person today due to my medication and life adjustments.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have suffered from severe fibromyalgia/chronic fatigue syndrome since 1983.  By nature, the disorder is resistant to treatment; as such, I have tried many different drugs in a desperate attempt to get well. I discovered that an antidepressant which reacts on both 5-HT & NE works best, and out of the three currently marketed, Effexor XR (150mg) worked best for me by far. It does have one colosal drawback, however; it is extremely expensive. Without insurance, 90 capsules, 150mg, in the US will set you back over $400. Cymbalta's efficacy compares favorably, but it's price also compares to Effexor XR 150mg caps. I tried milnacipran when it was only available in Europe, without success. In any case, if you are trying to overcome severe CFS, you're in for the fight of your life. GOOD LUCK!

column2: laurab, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

I found one cap per day was no effective in treating my depression, so I went back to my full dose and felt much better. I have found it is useful in treating many disorders - many of which I have and my doctors have been pleased I am already taking Effexor to help with these. column9: This drug worked great for me, I took it for about 6 years and was on 75mg.  The anxiety pretty much disappeared. If your anxiety is not that bad than I think xanax is much better and safer with no withdrawls because it's a fast-acting medication that leaves your system quickly.  I've recently "weaned" myself off Effexor and  while doing so experienced dizziness, moodiness, wierd brain/eye movement stuff, nervousness, did not sleep well for a few days, and tiredness which lasted about a week.  I plan to use the xanax as a PRN but so far have not had to use it, I also started to work out regularly a few years ago (martial arts) which I think helps the anxiety and is a much better alternative to medications.

column2: traceofmoon, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have tried several times to withdraw off of this medication.  Mentally, I have no problem if I withdraw gradually.  However, after about one month being off the drug, I develop IBS and gut related symptoms. Pain, extreme bloating, gurgling, pressure in the abdomen. It affects my life to the point that I do not even go out that much anymore. It is unbearable.  So, after awhile, I figured out that every time I stopped the Effexor XR, my gut problems returned.  I then have to go back on this medication.  I know that the gut is made up of 95% serotonin. Therefore, my gut area has become addicted to this medication.  I wish I could go off of it, but after trying many times, I must stay on it.  I sure hate to depend on this drug to keep my gut stable. I never had any problems previous to this medication.  I have been on these type of anti-depressants for 8 years, but on this type of anti-depressant for 4 years. Before that, I was on Prozac.

column2: moondust, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had a hysterectomy several years ago and was thrown head-first into what my doctor called "surgical menopause."  Then our family's retail store closed, my father died AND a five-year love relationship ended.  In short, I was a MESS and the 75mg timed-release dose was just what I needed.  It helped me tremendously, but there were unfortunate side effects: gained 40 lbs. in 4 years (size 12 to a size 16), let my house take care of itself (dust gathered and junk piled up), quit balancing my checkbook (unbelievable), and figured whatever it was I'd "get to it one of these days."  Originally paid about $95 for 30 caps, which was manageable, but the price kept going up (XR not available in generic).  Last month it jumped to $148.  That was IT.  Asked my doctor how to go about weaning myself off this drug; she suggested the generic non-XR 75mg tabs and cutting them in half, taking 1/2 in the morning and 1/2 in the afternoon, gradually going to 1/2 each morning and then none at all.  It's been 3 weeks and the gradual withdrawal seems to be working.  Side effects so far have been waking up in the middle of the night with hallucinations (birds flying around the room) and just feeling "out of body" at times - minimal, to say the least.  Have started walking and dusting again (checkbook is too overwhelming right now).  Whatever it takes, I intend to get my home and my body and my finances back on track.  And I WILL.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Caregiver)
column9: Also helps OCD tendency.

column2: yael, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

column1: Extreme Apprehension or Fear of Social Interaction
column2: colycole, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is my second time on effexor xr 75mg. The medicine worked great the first time for my extreme anxiety of everyday life.  I lived in a constant state of panic.  Yes, I agree the side effects can be terrifying and cause more anxiety.  I dealt with an increase heart rate and felt very nervous the first week both times.  However, I know this medicine works.  The first time on effexor xr for more than a year; I experienced the terrible effects if I missed a dose.  But, I also know whats its like not to even want your two precious children come towards you because they made nervous. I went back on the effexor when I also lost my fourteen year old daughter to Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever.  When you almost lose a child you realize its time to quit being young and stupid and think you can handle things on your own.  I would rather deal with some unwanted side effects and unpleasant feelings than to not enjoy my childrens life. Plus, I noticed the way I lived in fear affected my children.  And my daughter has shown signs of the same anxiety.  I realize getting help means helping to teach my children to enjoy and embrace everyday God gives us.  And if I am having a bad effexor day, I except that its not a good day and know tomorrow is a new day. Also, taking a 0.5 mg Xanax helps control the side effects when starting effexor xr.  It helps with the nervousness and rapid heart rate.  Took it three times a day the first week when starting and reduced the xanax til 2 a day and sometimes those are just half a pill.  Ask your dcotor about something to take the edge off when starting a effexor because it takes years or more for our nerves to get bad; so it takes the effexor some time to undo the damage our nerves has caused(there is no shame in it).

column2: Roger1987, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been suffering Long term depression. I sought out help in my final year of college. The Health Center DR put me on this and it worked. It worked for me for the whole time. There was one lul where watching a movie with a lighter in my hand (as i just lite a candle While watching 1408) the fire scene came on and i thought to myself... I could light this lighter and drop my hand and it would look like the movie. (I never have thought like that EVER) I was already working on coming off this drug as I was ALWAYS sweating and I wanted to end the medication life. Every night was filled with sweat, all winter long I was sweating, ACTUALLY I didnt mind it because I was warm when it was Cold. The other side effect I got was if I missed my dose even by 3 hours if I was walking I which ever direction i would turn that hand would go numb. The weaning off was not too hard, but I took it slow with an actual physician, I went down 37.5mgs each month. When it came to the end I felt like crap for about a week, the sweating ended after about a month. It has now been out of my system since March 09 and its July09. I look back at the last year and a lot of it, was a blur due to this medication.

column2: Butterfly, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was initially precscribed Effexor XR to treat my severe dailey migraines along with several other drugs At that time I was not diagnosed with depression although, I suspect my doctor thought that was the cause of my headaches. I had mild relief but, still had dailey headaches. About 4 years ago my doctor recommended Botox injections. We found that the combination of Effexor and the botox injections (every 3 months) was the winning combination. After 47 odd years of severe to incajpacitating migraines, I AM FINALLY HEADACHE FREE. I take one 250 mg Effexor in the morning and another at bedtime. As to side effects, I can't comment as I'm on several other medications with the same side effects, namely dry mouth and eyes.  However, it's more than worth it to only have occassional. normal headaches (like when it's approaching time for the botox) and very rarely a severe one.  I'm, naturally, very pleased with the Effexor. I was unaware of the withdrawal problems but, will probably be on it forever so I'm not worrying about that now.

column9: I WAS PUT ON 150 MG OF EFFEXOR WHEN CELEXA STOPPED WORKING FOR MY PANIC ATTACKS. column2: Searching for peace, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I am a male who has been on Effexor XR ap. 6+ years.  There was a notable positive difference when I started 37.5 mg qd dosage.  I could not believe the difference!!!  Gradually, my PCP gradually increased my dosage as time & incidents have occured.  Now, I am on 300mg qd - AM.My new XY is weaning me off Effexor XR for two weeks @ 150 mg qd - AM and as of now wants me to be totally off tomorrow (07-13-09).  Instead, I am to start Wellbutrin XL 150 mg qd starting tomorrow.  The "let down" from the Effexor XR has been horrible my second week.  I have had increasing amount of depression episodes; wanting to sleep all of the time; increasing muscle & joint ache; having hot and cold spells; having very restless periods; wanting to cry to rid myself of built-up internal tension; and having desire to be around "loved ones," but would rather be alone in bed sleeping.

column2: difficulty weaning off, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This medication worked well for me while taking it. If I missed a dose by even a few hours I would begin to get dizzy and have odd sensations in my brain. When I attempted to wean off the medication I had a lot of trouble. The Dr. lowered my dose to the lowest doseage and I did that for a while with minimal dizziness and odd sensations but everytime I tried to skip a day and get on that portion of the weaning off I would get terrible dizziness, bumping into things, hearing a creaking noise in my brain and having memory difficulties. My balance was entirely off. I did the one day inbetween for longer than my Dr. originally anticipated. The Dr. said he has never seen a patient have such difficulty weaning off a medication. I missed 2 days of work over the course of this and am on vacation as I write this. I haven't taken the medication at all in 4 days and the problems are fairly minimal. This has been more difficult to quit than quiting smoking. It concerns me that a medication can alter some process in the brain that when removing the medication from the system, following the process of doing so, causes such severe changes in my natural chemestry. I don't know if this experience is unique to me but if someone has difficulties with medications I would avoid this one if there is a different choice.

column9: I have been taken effexor 37.5 mg 1 time a day for about 6 months i have been dealing with depression,panic disorder,anxiety and major headaches for over 15 years i have use xanax,tramadol,topamax,prozac,paxil,neurontin,wel lbutrin,lexapro,and many more none of this meds helped. now with this med i also take restoril 15 mg 1 time,klonopin 1mg,fioricet ,and flexeril 10mg 1 time with the comb of meds i do get up in the morning and able to get thought the day but on the other and i think my doctor does not no want to do so when thing are not working he add a med changes the dose.i am thankful that i am living day to day and try not to stress about the little thing.

column2: Nikki, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was put on 300 mg of Effexor XR in 2002 and took this dosage until 2009.  If a dose was missed or late, I would immediately feel "shocks" throughout my entire body; like I was being electrocuted. It has been the most difficult and worst experience of my life to come off of these drugs.  It has taken several months for the withdrawals to stop even though I have been slowly weaning myself off.  During this time I have been extremely angry, self destructive and suicidal.  I truly did not think I would make it.  The coming off effexor part has been so terrible that I cannot remember if it worked for me for all those years or not.  My doctor did not offer any support except to say that "everyone goes through the "shock" feelings...You just have to deal with it".  Obviously she had never been through this as I am sure most doctors will never get themselves hooked on these drugs.  I did not know what to do.  If it weren't for my husband & family I am 90% sure I would have killed myself.  I will never allow my body to become addicted to these types of medications again.  Please do not take the first doctor's prescription and believe that he/she has your best interest in mind.  Please seek second or third opinions.  Drug companies offer incentives to doctors for selling their "drug" and as we all know, anti-depressants are the trendy, hot drug and there is so much competition the pharmaceutical companies have to push doctors to prescribe their brand.  I am not saying that medication should never be used; it helps many, many people - just PLEASE protect yourself. I am telling you now, if you start Effexor XR, you will end up taking it everyday for the rest of your life or you will go through the worst pain, depression, anger you will ever experience trying to get off Effexor XR AND you cannot do it by yourself - you need someone to watch out for you.
Has alleviated panic attacks.

column2: Bermie, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have taken 150 mg daily for over a year after changing from other meds like Lexepro and Wellbutin. I found that the Effexor XR worked well. I have recently taken myself off this medication. There were side effects to stopping such as vision difficulties, nausea, vomiting and sleep disturbances but, not as difficult as I thought from the reviews. I can only believe that because of my large weight, it did not effect me as bad as some other reviewers. I am trying to stay off all depression meds and go with more homeopathic remedies, exercise and routine.

column2: Rachelle S., 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have had mixed results with Effexor XR.  (I took it for several years before switching to Pristiq a few months ago.)  Initially and for several years after starting Effexor XR, it did a good job treating my depression associated with Bipolar Disorder (I take mood-stabilizers as well!)  Effexor XR was, at one time, the best anti-depressant I had ever taken in terms of mood symptoms.  I did have some gastrointestinal side-effects; diarrhea and stomach-aches.  However, I medicated those in addition to taking the Effexor XR, because the Bipolar was "a bigger issue."  After approx. 4 years though, the effect from the Effexor XR diminished and I had to take an increased dose, which brought more side-effects and less impact on elevating my mood.  If I ever missed a dose of Effexor XR or took it a bit late, my head would feel dizzy and horrible.  I went off the medication twice.  Once, (a former) doctor did not have another anti-depressant for me to switch too and that was a nightmare, both with bad side-effects and mood issues.  The second (and final) time I discontinued the Effexor XR, I started Pristiq and my new doctor helped make a very smooth transition by decreasing the Effexor XR and increasing the Pristiq.  So, overall, Effexor XR may prove very effective, but may have some side-effects.

column2: 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
effexor VICTIM, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: THIS IS A HORRIBLE DRUG!!!!! HIGHLY ADDICTIVE!!!! DO NOT TAKE!!!I have watched my mother, who has never taken a recreational drug in her life struggle with this drug almost killing her (literally) from the withdrawl symptoms. She began taking it to treat her hot flashes and depression and built up to 225mg. All was well and wonderful, that is until she ran out of insurance, lost her company and could no longer afford the outrageously expensive drug. She stopped taking the drug and began to feel like she was shutting down, physically and mentally. I have struggled with opiate addiction for a few years now and i think there is no worse feeling than the withdrawl you experience when quitting. that was until i saw my mom go through this. she went to the hospital for what she was feeling (not knowing it was effexor withdrawl) and they told her that her body was literally shutting down. Once she started telling them the medication and dose she was on, they knew right away it was the effexor. since then she has only been able to ween down to 75mgs, due to the fact that YOU CAN LITERALLY DIE FROM THE WITHDRAWL OF THIS DRUG. She feels too awful when she tries to take any lower of a dose. She feels like she cant control any mental functions, she feels out of body, horrific nightmares, can't sleep right, complete physical drain, awful rages. And thats just the symptoms that wont actually kill you!!!Just take the time to research the class action lawsuit against Wyeth. And the thousands of blogs about the people going through the same things i have described here. Please just don't take this drug, i wouldn't wish this experience on my worst enemy.
