column2: wickedhalo, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am a 29 yr. old married mother of one son and have been on Effexor for 6 months now after being on Cymbalta for only a cpl of months. I stopped the Cymbalta due to the cost! I love love love this med. I always have felt heavy with burden, or have had social anxiety, couldn't stand to talk to ANYONE if i wasn't interested in the conversation. I could agree with them all day long but not even remember what the conversation was about later! I had NO interest in anyones thoughts, ideas, or conversations, or life stories! I could only see the pos. effects from this med. when it finally regulated in my body, which was roughly a constinous month without missing a single dose! I became more engaged in conversations with people, was truly interested with what they had to say, and was able to comprehend what was being said to remember it later! I am more happy with life in general, i'm more laid back and just about accepting of whatever burdens or stress that heads my way! I do have VERY vivid dreams( almost life like), I STILL have NO SEXUAL DRIVE AT ALL! I DO NOT like that and neither does my husband! I AM NOT ABLE TO ORGASM, I HAVE GAINED ABOUT 15LB.S IN 6 MONTHS, i have less desire to get up and do the things i once loved (waxing my car, cutting grass, and MAINLY cleaning)! Its a toss-up for me on wether or not its worth taking the meds and dealing with the neg. side effects, or going back to being a selfish, inconsiderate individual that loved the outdoors!  I love the possitive sides and ABSOLUTLY HATE THE NEG. I hope this information has help a user that has some questions!

column2: Dmac, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Effexor XR 75mg for over 2 years and I like it the most. I tried Lexapro (did not like and did not seem to work), Paxil (worked but was too powerful with side effects), Remeron (did not seem to work and had little to no side effects), and Welbutrin (did not seem to work as well as Effexor "for me"). One thing is for sure, all of these meds cause grief when missing a dose or trying to stop. Paxil was by far the worst if I missed a dose. I have always taken low dosages of these meds but they seem to even me out. Effexor does not cause side effects at 75mg but at 150mg I was having libo issues and it did not seem to help me in any way that was apparent or measureable. Effexor XR can be missed for about one day but come the second day I get headaches, the zaps and dizzy headed. Some of the other meds I tried could not be missed by one day without terrible withdrawl symptoms. I might try a Welbutrin/Effexor combo but it will be a minimal dose for both. I have no idea why people think a pill is not easy to use and rate drugs that are pills less than 5 stars??? Put it in your mouth and swallow :)

In addition, I WISH I had the reduction of appetite...still eating just fine.  Overall, works great for me.

column9: I've been on Effexor XR for over 2 yrs and found it OK.  I've been on so many other anti-depressants that their effects eventually wore off. column1: Extreme Apprehension or Fear of Social Interaction
column2: wickedhalo7924, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been on Effexor XR for social anxiety and slight depression due to a raw up bringing in my childhood, that were at the hands of my father! I have been taking the Effexor XR for almost 3 months after being on Cymbalta, and the generic for Effexor, due to the fact that Cymbalta didn't help me much and taking two doses of the generic effexor just about made me puke because of the taste. For the first couple weeks of taking it, i swore that it was a waste of time and most deffinatley money! I continued doctors orders and took my medicine on a regular basis! I am glad that i did because after my body regulated the drug i have seen a great difference. I am much more happier, content, and i don't loose my cool at the drop of a dime! I am able to focus 10 times better and i am able to socialize much easier than before! It has done wonders for me! I found that taking my med. before i go to sleep rather than early in the morning when i awoke made me feel better and help curve the appetites and cravings! This drug makes you pretty hungry and wanting to snack all the time. So by taking it before i go to sleep helped me bypass all the cravings and snacking! my dreams became more vivid or "real life like" but i would rather the dreams than the weight gain! The only down side to this medication that i have experienced so far is minor headaches, (including sinus), and only once since taking the med. i felt like snapping and being extremely pissed off, (most likely due to my body trying to regulate the drug), gaining weight, (I ABSOLUTLY hate it). I am retaining ALOT of fluid. I have an appointment Fri. so hopefully i will be able to get the water retention under wraps! I have not expierenced the brain "zaps", nausea, or any other negative side affects that many users talk about on the reviews of this drug! I hope that some of this information has helped other users, and or reviewers that are thinking about taking Effexor XR. Everyone is different when it comes to narcotics!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have always had the normal bouts with anxiety but around 6 months ago, while I was away on a conference trip, I began having anxiety attacks (excelerated heatbeat, feeling of something bad was going to happen if I drive over the bridge). Then when I got home, the anxiety got worse.  I felt like I was losing my mind, totally unlike myself. I decided I needed to see my doctor immediately because I knew something was not right.  He gave me Effexor-I started on 37.5 dose for 10 days, then increased to 75mg a day.  The first time I took it, I felt this overwhelming sensation of cool happiness and I knew it was going to help me.  My anxiety didn't completely go away but it has made a huge difference in how I felt during that time.  My doctor said he can increase the dosage but I didn't want to for fear of being overly medicated and too dependent on it.  Now that I have been on it for 6 months, I feel okay to increase it, if need be.  I am a little apprehensive of what type of withdrawal side effects I will feel, but I am confident in my doctor and will follow his instructions to decrease my dosage slowly.  I know everybody has their own experience with this medication, but I wanted to share mine in hope's that it will help someone feel okay about taking it.  I had not intended to write this review but I read the guy's experience who wrote on 5/30/09 @ 3:21pm and it touched me.  So I hope this will help someone. Also, turning to my faith, family, and friends has been a tremendous help.

column2: skibberdeen, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This drug along with other Psych drugs  that are salt based can cause Dry Mouth Disease.  My teeth haave rotted out from the inside out and treatment for this has caused me constant pain and depression.  The Doctor who first set me on tjhis med did not tell me about the dry mouth so I am losing a mouthfull of what were perfectally good teeth.  Be sure your Doctor tells you EVERYTHING about this and anyother Psych med thew want you to take.

column2: screw effexor, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: It was like being of an extacy pill.i tried to kill my self would not reccomend.

column2: Got help, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I must be lucky. I'm on 37.5mg 2x per day, have been for about 4 months. After 5 years of depressive symptoms & then being diagnosed with PTSD, I have to say my life has completely turned around. The only side effect has been minor headaches, but thankfully not daily. It did take some time to work & some days I am "moody" but I chalk that up to the normalacy of life. I get along better with everyone, can drive, be in groups & deal with stressors better than I remember. If you are considering this med, give it a chance to work & think about combining it with conventional therapy (talking to someone). I highly recommend!

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Had anx. most my life.  Then hit with some depression few months ago. Wow, that's no fun.  I will never say to someone, "hey snap out of it" Life works in funny ways sometimes.  Anyways, was forced to get help with the depression. Started with lowest dose 37.5 for 10 days, then 75mg for 14 days and to date at 75 + 37.5 = 112.5mg.  The hardest part was waiting for it to work, It took atleast 5/6 weeks. I wanted to quit many times, but stuck with it. Weird side effects along the way but help from Dr., Therapist and friends helped. The other problem was I expected when it did work to immediately make the depression just go away.  Found out "it don't work that way" I guess the depression came on slowly (thou I never realized) and it goes away slowly.  So I seemed to feel best in the evening and worst in the morning. Dr. said that's normal with depression. The other hurdle to get over is I'll be feeling like my old self for a day or two and "boom" out of the clear blue it creeps back.  Which at first really scared me and pissed me off.  How dare it, after all that hard work. But, with patience I slowly start feeling better again. Quite a roller coaster ride. To date, I have more better days than bad days. Having to work hard at feeling just "normal" does suck.  But life is worth it. With so many horrible things that can happen to us, I try to feel fortunate compared to those who have no real hope.  Regarding people with suicide thoughts, as long as you keep them as thoughts, just don't act on them.  I'm sure every adult has wondered about suicide at some point. Someone once told me that suicide is a "Final solution to a Temporary problem". Think about it very true.Depression/Anx are the most treatable of mental disorders.  So hang in there, take baby steps, and believe in the BIG Guy.  That's all I'm doing.

column2: bert, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on effexor xr 225mg for 11-12 years now. i recently had a pharmacy mix up and have reduced my dosage to 150mg.  it took a couple of weeks to feel normal again but i am surprised at all the side effects that people report.  other than night sweats, weird dreams and lowered sexual desire, i don't notice many other symptoms. i fear going off of this completely though which is why i have been on it so long.

column2: cold as ice, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have decided to stop taking Effexor. It has only been a month, however I have been eating like a pig, very drowsy, very irritable and I cant seem to get rid of this headache. I have been weaning myself off the Effexor for a few days now. The only thing that I have experienced so far is pain behind my eyes. Weird! I will begin Wellbutrin next month. I hope this one helps me!

column2: jporter, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor XR worked great for my depression and anxiety but I need to come off it (it's too expensive) and the withdrawal is horrible. I have been off it for a week and I am constantly dizzy (even feel dizzy in my dreams) and often nauseous.  I am also really irritable and am trying to avoid my co-workers so I don't bite anyone's head off for no reason. When I'm not irritable I feel weepy and lately anxious and paranoid.  I have already started taking Wellbutrin and I think it is helping.  It is very frustrating that none of the literature talks about length of withdrawal symptoms.  I know it's different for everyone but surely someone has measured this in a test group and can publish the results from that group.  I haven't even been able to find a comment anywhere from someone saying they managed to get off it and are now finally feeling better.  Very disheartening.  Published tests of new drugs should include discontinuation symptoms and observed length of those symptoms. There is no good reason to exclude that data.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I suffered from anxiety attacks and  depression for many years before accepting the fact that needed help controlling my emotions and (suicidal) thoughts.  It helps me get through the day and helps me sleep better at night.  I began taking Effexor 6 years ago, starting with the lowest dosage, currently I take the highest dosage.  It must be taken daily for it to be effective, and be warned, do NOT stop taking it cold turkey.  Missing a pill causes vertigo (dizziness), nausea and fatigue.  The drug does not mix well with alcohol.  If you do drink, be advised, you will 'hit the wall' rather quickly, and likely sprial into a depression episode.  If taken correctly it is a miracle drug and I plan on taking it the rest of my life. It may not be for everyone, but it probably saved my life.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: Went on this Med. in Dec.2008 and I have to say this medication worked for me. No side- effects that I notice. I am in no rush to get off. Anxiety does not happen over night, so it takes time and the medication will only do so much-the rest is up to you. you.

column2: jcfsusmc, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor has saved my life and relationships.  After going through a series of therapies for major depression, it was discovered that I had a major case of ADHD with anxiety and panic cohorts (at the age of 48!).  This diagnosis explained everything that was me.  I was referred to a PA (believe it or not!) who worked with Psych MD's and started me on Effexor.  It was almost an instant relief of my anxiety.  After two months, I was at 150mg per day.  Now, to get off ritalin without driving everyone mad.  Without ritalin, I am now on 300 mg per day, with 300 mg of Wellbutrin to boot!  Yes, I'm an extreme case, but it's disconcerting that most of the reviews are negative.First, I was on several drugs for a while that didn't really work.  I agree that Effexor shouldn't be a first line of defense.  But if it works, why worry about the withdrawals?  I don't ever want to stop taking Effexor.  My wife and kids can approach me 24/7 even with bad news.  I have no stress except eustress.  I can keep my cool, ignore messy people, gossip, and know it alls!One other thing - why is Effexor not advertised (by the doctors) more for treatment of moderate to severe AD/HD?I have nothing but high praise for Effexor.  It saved my marriage, my family, my work, among other things.

column2: sophiespike, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This medication works well for me. I would not say my depression has lifted 100%, which is a rare case, but probably about 80%, which gets me through most days. It was prescribed about 5-6 yrs ago by my PCP, when I saw him for the first time. I had been on Lexapro, Celexa and Paxil previously, (not at the same time), but with each of those meds, after taking them for about 6 months to a year, I began to have very very vivid dreams, not exactly nightmares, but vivid enough to really disturb my sleep and not allow me to function well the next day. This HAS NOT happened with EFFEXOR XR 150mg, even after all this time. Also, about 2 yrs ago I was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia,and we tried taking me off Effexor a few months ago and going on Cymbalta, to kill two birds with 1 stone, so to speak, but I had a horrible reaction to the Cymbalta (the Fibro actually got much worse) and I went back to Effexor. This seems to be the best antidepressant for me with the fewest side effects, maybe dry mouth, and some sleepiness, nothing major. Unless I miss a dose. DO NOT MISS A DOSE! If you wish to reduce your dosage or get off the drug altogether, do not do so without a dr's advise, otherwise you will feel like a truck hit you.My conclusion, for me: it works, and I will continue to use it.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Ok, basically when I was 14 my mom moved to Germany, and I was left to take care of my dad.  I started this medication after being severely depressed.  It was a great drug while I was on it.  I didnt cry all the time, or anything like that.  In fact, I was quite numb to everything around me.  But after 3 years or so of being on it, I was going to lose my insurance, and Effexor is way too expensive, so I decided to get off of it.  And let me tell you, that was the worst decision I have ever made.  The withdrawal effects were so severe.  I ended up checking into a psychiatric ward.  I had brain zaps, nausea, constant crying.  In fact, it is a year after I stopped taking this medication, and I still have severe nausea.  This medication was good while I was on it.  So basically, if you are prescribed this medication, plan on being on it for the rest of your life.I would not recommend this to anyone..

column2: Regretful, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I began taking 75mg for severe hot flashes 2 years ago.  It worked almost immediately for about 1 year and then the hot flashes came back but not as severe.  My doctor wanted to increase my dose but I opted not to.  Thank goodness I made this decision.  I have been trying to wean myself off this drug for 2 months very gradually.  Every change came with symptoms.  I am now down to 37.5; on one day; off two.  Everytime I try to go to off 3 days I feel like I have the flu and worse is the fact that my brain is disfunctional.  I am dizzy, confused and cannot concentrate.  This in addition to nausea and fatigue.  I want off this drug so badly because it eventually made me feel "nothing".  I went to a funeral of a very good friend and felt nothing.  I have not cried in over a year even though I want too.  I am miserable and I am going to try just not taking it again.  It should be offered in a lower dose for weaning off purposes.  If I knew that I would have to go through this, I would have put up with the hot flashes instead!  These symptoms are so severe, I don't feel like I should drive or work.  I am also irritable and my family is finding me difficult to live with.  The doctor who prescribed to me is a GYN and I don't think she had knowledge of these horrific side effects either.  How long will it take before I feel better?

column9: After trying other meds (wellbutrin, zoloft,celexa) without measurable success, my family doc put me on effexor xr. It's been almost 3 years. column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was on Effexor for Depression and Anxiety and suffering major side effects but did not realize it was the Effexor until I experienced excessive and embarrassing facial sweating and asked to come off it - knowing that my Dr would replace it with another drug if needed. I had headaches 5-7 times a week but thought that was just me - I've had headaches for years.  I was fatigued but thought I just had no will power to exercise, and improve my fitness.   I would only sleep about 5 hours a night, I had no energy.   I was slower in everything I did eg, speech, typing, decision making domestic chores.     During the Dr-scheduled withdrawal I had headaches, diarrhea, shakes and felt dreadful - I was sent home from work twice. AFTER withdrawing  the facial sweating and headaches STOPPED;  I had increased libido and upswings in moods.  My speed of speech, processing, decision making and implementation increased significantly (I work in an environment where constant statistics are taken throughout every shift.  I have gone from 'Performance Management" - ie, your performance is below standard and your job is at risk - to beating targets in an incredibly short period of time - since withdrawing from the Effexor¬).The downside is that after a honeymoon period of about 10-12 days my anxiety increased so much that today I have been put on another medication  (Lexapro) to control it.  I'M HOPING my body will better tolerate it  however I will know better what to look for instead of assuming these problems are all personal attributes uninfluenced by medication side effects as everyone of them improved since coming off the Effexor.  SUMMARY:The Effexor definitely controlled depression and anxiety (though from time to time I still felt both) but the cost in side effects was VERY high and if the facial sweating had not started YEARS after taking the medication, indicating I was experiencing a side effect, I would still be taking Effexor & suffering all of the side effects, whic

column9: I had a severe bout of depression after several traumatic events all at once. I also suffer from GAD. I started on Lexipro (nothing), Wellbutrin (bad experience), then Effexor which worked well. I started at 75mg and eventually increased to 150mg. Things are going well in my life now and I have learned a lot about coping (with God's help), so I have decided to get off Effexor after 4 years. I have reduced to 75mg with some of the side effects described. I am waiting on the next step from my doctor.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor XR has been the ONLY medication that has helped me with my depression/anxiety. I've tried Paxil and Wellbutrin in the past without any benefit. I noticed a difference within the first few days of taking Effexor XR. No side effects...but I'm dreading the day that I have to get off this medication due to all the horror stories I've read. I don't plan on getting off it anytime soon!

column2: ??, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor XR has been the only consistent drug, when used in combination with others, to effectively control chronic depression. The side effects are dry mouth, an abundance of mental energy and feeling quite comfortable, not wanting to venture out of the house or do errands. It doesn't interfere with sexual activity (as it does for some). I can, but prefer not to drive for @ 2 hours after dosing. I am convinced that I have been in 2 minor fender benders due to rapid thinking and acting. Generally I am so glad not to be in a fetal position or wanting to sleep the entire day, that the side affects are "doable"

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years
column9: I have been on 450mg for over a year when the medication stopped working. Up until then it was the only med that worked for my major depression. I tried many; Zoloft, Welbutrin, Paxil, Seroquel, Lithium, amoung others. I'm currently taking Limictil and tapering off Effexor 75mg at a time. So far I'm tired, but that's not uncommon for me. I'm getting sinus headaches. It's my time for allergies. My pattern is fall apart on Saturdays. Headache, sleep, fatigue. I've put up with so much from my depression and gone on with my life as best I can. If I have to sleep all day on Saturday, oh well. I plan to not do anything on Saturdays. I've stopped expecting miracles from medication. They help but I'll always deal with this disease.

column2: here2help, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Hello like many others that have taken this drug I HATE it!!!! I began effexor to treat migraines. I suffered from many of the common side effects moodiness, constipation, inability to become sexually aroused, dehydration, and weight gain. The worst part about the drug is that it is next to impossible to get off of. But I DID IT!!! You need to start by weening yourself down to the lowest dose (37.5mg). Once there take the capsule pills only. Open the capsule and each day take out 5 of the small round balls. If you feel so sick from the removal stay at that level until you feel ok. Example remove 10 for three days instead of moving on to 15 if you are feeling sick. Keep doing this until you get down to 0. It took over three months but I am finally off this dreaded medication after 3 years. It is not easy but just after a month of not being on it i feel amazing and my sex life has already changed and i am having more frequent bowel movements. This is the ONLY way to get off it. Trust me i have tried cold turkey and the skipping tablets it does NOT work. Good luck and please get off of this medication and on to something else ASAP. I hope this helps :)

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on and off effexor xr for 10 years, works well. I have also taken the new Pristiq, it helps but less for GAD.(even though they are basically the same thing-and metabolize differently. The best way to get off the effexor xr is reduce your dose to 37.5 and take 5mg or 10mg prozac. After 1 week discontinue the effexor and continue to take the prozac for 3 to 4 weeks. This should help minimize the withdrawls, everyone is different so you can tweek it to your needs. I have done this many times... anyway this is food for thought for people that are having problems getting off of it!!I hope it helps!

column9: I have noticed that I can't get off this medication cause if I try I feel so sick very dissy can't even turn my head with out every thing spinning.It's horrible side effect. How do I get off of it, can anyone tell me.

column2: Brain Zap Victim, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This drug was very helpful with my depression, anxiety and panic attacks.  However, after 4 years of using this medication, I am now trying to come off of it and experiencing withdrawal symptoms that are beyond anything I would have imagined.  The "brain zaps" are the worst.  I will accept the fever, muscle pain, restless legs (which include muscle spasms), fatigue, nightmares, vertigo, crying spells and irrational outbursts - but - something that is truly best described as brain zaps - no, that I will not accept.  It is absolutely terrible that this drug is allowed on the market.  There has to be something else out there to treat depression, axiety and panic disorder that does not require such severe withdrawal symptoms.  I feel like a heroin addict or something... ridiculous!  It has been 6 days so far and everything that I have read says that I am no where near out of the woods.  I just pray that this feeling in my brain - that really feels like my brain has been pressed against an electric fence - will subside.  I have now missed days at work due to these symptoms.  I really hope that people consider the withdrawals before taking their doctors word at this drug.  There HAS to be something else.

column9: i AM ON 150MG. A DAY FOR 6 MO. AND IT IS WORKING.  I HAVE BEEN ON PAXIL (TERRIBLE) AND ZOLOFT AL(DIDN'T WORK) AND FEEL MUCH BETTER NOW.  THE DOWN SIDE IS I SWEAT ALOT WHEN I DO SOMETHNG PHYSICAL.  THAT'S OK BECAUSE I FEEL ALOT BETTER.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was on Effexor 225mg for a coupl years, and I had a great experience. After trying a couple other medications to treat my depression and slight anxiety, Effexor worked wonders. However, I have since been weaned off of it in the past few months (trying to get pregnant), and I have found that, while my depression has lessened, my anxiety and irritablity has gown through the roof. It is far worse than it was before I was put on the effoexor in the first place. I am now taking Buspar for my anxiety because it may be a little safer for pregnancy, but I am still incredibly high strung. I plan to get back on it after my pregnancy. While I would recommend Effexor to others who suffer from depression, just beware of potential side effects if you ever have to taper off of the medication.

column2: momoftwins1971, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had been taking Ativan as needed for about 3 years now and last December, it started to become less-effective. I was very hesitant to start taking this medication due to a bad episode with Lexapro about 5 years ago. I'm on 75 mg and getting used to this drug was no picnic. Although the side effects were rough, I had to admit that there were periods of "calm" that made me think if this is how I was going to feel when I was used to the medication, then this IS worth it.I've been on the medication for about 4 months now and it's been pretty good so far. I no longer have panic attacks and surprisingly rarely get nervous before giving presentations at work (something I could barely do before). One of the only things that I don't like is that I seem a bit "numb" and have become more forgetful. I sometimes have a hard time concentrating, too. I've read about the symptoms of withdrawal, which alone would make me stay on this drug...especially if it was like the side effects I had when I started it. My family says that I seem more happy and less anxious. I've had no problems facing situations that used to make me feel uncomfortable, which is a huge plus. I'm able to go to the theater, be in large crowds, and my "nervous stomach" seems to have disappeared! My next test is a plane trip we're taking late in May. If I can get through that trip without incident, then I feel almost "cured." Overall, I'm glad I gave it a chance and wish I would have done this years ago.

column2: antieffexorxr, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Started taking 75 mg 2-3 years ago and it worked well. I decided to go off of it 3 days ago and it has been hell. I have been experiencing the following:1.paresthesias with electric shock sensations2.feeling of shocks in the brain3.confusion4.tinnitus5.dry mouth6.dizziness7.impaired coordination and balance8.agitation9.irritability10.nausea 11.hightened anxiety12.Zooming feeling in the eyesThe worst is the electrical shock feeling in the brain. Like i said it did a good job helping with the anxiety but BE AWARE of the serious side effects when stopping. All the i have listed that i have experienced are listed right in the official effexor xr website. I wish i would have know this stuff prior to because i would have seriously concidered not taking it. So i have been having "withdrawals" for 3 days now and they havent given at all. I hope this doesnt last much longer!

column9: I have been on this medication for several year, believing it stopped working since my anxiety came back at times, and I was really moody, irritable, and depressed more and more.So I went to my doctor, he suggested getting me off of effexor, and putting me on celexa instead. I was to go 2 weeks lower does of effexor and then 4 days later add the celexa. Well rollercoaster ride I was on the first three days of lowering the dose to 75mg I was wired with energy you wouldnt believe then slowly felt better with the celexa it took a little bit for me to get used to the medication switch and so forth. Well now its been two weeks off of the effexor and its a very hard drug to get off so just be careful. I have felt very dizzy, lightheadedness at times throughout the day. It feels as though you have had nothing to eat and your sugar is dropping even if you have eaten already. That shakey tingly feeling. You will have it in spurts for a few days, you might get panic attacks if you have had trouble with them in the past. They dont last long but they last for only about 10 minutes or so. I hope this was helpful for any of you getting off of it.

column2: bobo, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I am so grateful - this drug has given me the chance to live - my anger and anxiety have largely disappeared - Not only can i handle long and somewhat high stress situations now (work/sales travelling) - but i know i can before entering them - this brings confidence which allows me to enjoy the moment and the people around me - i can laugh gently and smile big because I'm so happy experiencing people and situations without stress/fear is almost intoxicating - people are liking me so much more - i am liking me so much more - i am living and so grateful - God, am I grateful - my life has changed and I have a shot that i NEVER had before - I am able to give my wife and kids who i love terribly the emotional safety and peace that they so desperately deserved - shoulda found this medicine 20 yrs ago when i got sober - now on for 1 full yr - 75mg per day - always struggled with weight but it has kinda jumped up quite high - i also noticed someone mention something about vision - my reading glasses have gone from +1.25 to +2.50 in this past year - and it's surprised me, but who knows I just turned 48

column9: felt very sick for first week after that all went well.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was 17 when I went on this, there wasn't even a generic out there yet, and while it managed to lessen the depression to where I could manage through the day, it didn't really make me feel all that better.  I was on the highest legal dosage at the time (I don't know if it's changed since then) and would get horrid nightmares if I forgot to take it, and it made me sleepy all the time.  Since going off, I can't remember a lot of what happened that year I was on it, and I developed intense sensitivity in my two front teeth, particularly troublesome as a clarinetist.  I discovered after a visit to an endodontist that they sometimes use this to block nerves to the teeth.  Had I been aware of this possible side effect, I never would have taken it.  My career as a clarinetist ended at 19 because the drug was too new and doctors didn't know it could do this to me.  I never wanted to go on anti-depressants in the first place, and I'm not happy I was on this.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
BVM, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Effexor XR 75 mg for 7 years after an deep depressive episode resulting from major life changes & aging, as well as hereditary.  They started me on Paxil, but it was way too intense.   Effexor has worked well for me, a side benefit has been that it has reduced my anxiety tremondously which is also enherited.  The side effects have been some tinnitus (ringing in ears), undoubteldy due to elevated blood pressure, but not extreme.  Also lower libido but at my age I don't care.   I have not experienced signficant weight gain.  It is livable.  This drug as allowed me to function in a high stress workplace effectively.   I have no doubt I could not do this job without it, plus I am not stressed about homelife either.  A lifesaver.   I don't know if I could or should ever go off it knowing my hereditary traits, and reading about the withdrawal symptoms. No one seems to know if there are long term side effects, but at least I can live normally for now.

column2: sudharris, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I am a VA patient and have been hospitalized four times for depression associated with PTSD. I've been on so many antidepressants that I can't recall all the names. My first drug was Elivil; the night I took it was the first night I had slept 8 hours in years. For one reason or another, I tried and stopped using many other drugs. I was suicidal and homocidal on Prozac after 3 months of "heaven," had horrible shakes and anxiety on Zoloft, no effect with Paxil and others. Finally, was put on Effexor and it worked to keep me alive. My rages began escalating about two years ago and my psychiatrist added buspirone. I am now "in control" but like others here, I gained 40 pounds, have no sex drive, sweat heavily (especially from the head), don't have much energy, have problems with memory, and my body lets me know when I forget to take my pills (dizzy, unbalanced). I may have severe withdrawals if I quit the drug, but I think I'll probably be on them for the rest of my life, so I'm not going to worry about.  In the long run, I would much rather have the side effects than feel like I'm in Hell day in and day out; have nightmares; wish (pray)for death; live alone because I can't get along with anyone; be a threat to anyone who tips my rage scale over the edge. It was a long road and many years (1995 from diagnosis to 2004) before my phyciatrists and I found the right antidepressant and the right dosage. Don't give up trying!

column2: fatso, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was given Effexor XR for bipolar disorder. i have now been taking the medication (225m) per day for a year and a half, since then I have gained 30lbs. I'm more depressed over the weight gain than I was with the bipolar symptoms.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was on this for about 3 years, it worked but I had undesirable side effects, such as weight gain, lack of sexual desire. My Dr. and I decided to get me off it and switch to Wellbutrin. He gave me a step down program to decrease gradually. It did NOT work. I had SEVERE problems, tingly all over my body, my head felt like I was having an out of body experience,nausea, exhausted, could not function, body aches. The worse was that horrible tingly feeling from head to toe! It took me a total of 10 months to successfully get off this nasty drug. I would NOT recommend this to anyone!

column2: add1540, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years
column9: I was prescribed this med in Jan 1998 for extreme depression.  After a month with no change, the Dr increased it to the maximum manufacturer's dosage (I was 95 lbs).  The depression lifted like magic and I felt alive again. The Dr insisted I remain on this med at this high dose and after 2 1/2 yrs my weight gain of 50 lbs...!!! became a depression in itself, had drawers and a closet full of clothes I couldn't fit into anymore. I was horrified. This med made me CRAVE food and especially sweets..and I'm not by nature a sweet eater.  I changed Drs in July 2000 and he was surprised at the large dose I was on, took me off of it completely.  My experience was that it worked, it had several side effects as they all do, but the huge dose for the extended time was detrimental in the long run.

column2: 55-64 Female  (Patient)
column9: Having a lot of trouble finding the rightcombination of drugs to help me.  Right nowI am on lamotrigine (generic for lamictal)and Effexor XR.  I am loosing my hair ata very fast rate.  Do not know if thisis being cause by one or the other grug.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been on 37.5 for 3 months for anxiety no depression. At first there were some side effects like headache, hot flashes, and a couple of extreme panic attacks.  Those went away within the 1st week.  Now I have vivid nightmares but still sleep well.  I feel great overall.  I am a full time working mom of 3 and working on my master's degree.  I feel great. No more panic attacks. No more aches and pains or worries.  I am worried about coming off the meds when the time is right, but feel great. This is my first time taking any meds for this.  The most of anything I've taken is an antibiotic. It's great. I keep in contact with my doc with check ups, and the current lowest dose works for me.  It was difficult for me to admit I was having anxiety and panic attacks. good luck to all

column2: mistala, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: At first WebMD REALLY freaked me out; reading all of the "avoid this medicine" reviews from users.  There were many stories from people that scared me.  I told my Dr. about them and of course he said, "yeah, there are many skeptics out there ESPECIALLY on the web."  Well, he was right.The drug has been very effective.  I gradually built up to 150mg.  In the past I've taken lexapro (effective also, but gained weight) and wellbutrin (totally ineffective, lost weight).  This drug is a very happy medium. It's effective and I haven't gained weight.  I'm extremely satisfied with the results.  I feel a lot more stable, my anxiety has gone WAY WAY down, and overall I am really back to being myself. I started feeling the effects of it about 3 weeks into taking it.  My purpose of writing is really to say - everyone has their own experience with these drugs.  You may need to try a few.  The most important thing is to, when coming off, speak with your doctor and do it slowly - you should have a problem, really.

column2: abby, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I love this medicine. I have less depression and more energy. I wish they would have tried this before all the others. It is true..different people need different medicine, and this one is for me.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on this drug for about 10 years now and it has helped me out in so many ways.  I would like to stop taking this medication because of the cost and not having insurance,  it is too expenisive for me.  I have read horror stories after horror storys about the withdrawl systems and I am scared to go off it now.  I wish my doctor would have warned me of this effect before putting me on this drug.  Also the mfg of this drug in my opion charges way to much for this drug.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Was put on Effexor XR for anxiety gradually increased up to 150 mg 1x/day and have been on it for approx 3.5 years, after my life has calmed down I decided to get off.  My Dr took me off SLOWLY changing the dose every two weeks (2wks at 150/75 alt days, 2 wks at 75/day, 2 wks at 75/37.5 alt days, 2wks at 37.5/day, 2 wks at 37.5/nothing alt days, then off) I have now been Effexor freevfor one full week and I am still suffering from withdrawl symptoms that seem to be getting worse by the day.  I didn't have a problem with the withdrawl symptoms while transitioning until now.  I'm dizzy, my brain feels like its swimming, and my sleep schedule just depends on the day  (sometimes I can sleep sometimes I can't).  Being a nurse I realize that taking medication that alter mood and all that will have withdrawl symptoms but I NEVER realized that anything could be this bad.  The medication worked and served its purpose (without side effects) while taking it but I suggest talking to your doctor about what happens down the road when you try to get off.  Unfortunatley you never know how your body will react until that time comes but maybe there are other medications out there that are easier to transition off of without feeling like a zombie!  Hope this helps!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)

column2: abooch33, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: DO NOT TAKE THIS!!!!! Took this for a year, no real relief, tried to stop taking twice and the withdrawals were so bad I had to return to taking it. Most docs are unaware of the severe withdrawals. DO NOT try to stop cold turkey! Even forgetting a dose will start the brain "zaps/shivers" because of the short half-life of this med, and they are horrible! To get off of these with mild withdrawls, I had to break open the capsuls and SLOWLY start to decrease the amount inside. I took away about 1/4 and took 3/4 of the beads for a week or two, then brought it down to a half, then down to 1/2 of a 1/2, then to just however many would stick to a couple finger tips full, took about 6 weeks to wean myself off. It was awful. You couldn't pay me enough to take this drug EVER again!

column9: For the past few weeks I was suffering from anxiety and depression that came out of nowhere. I was having unwanted thoughts and fears that I knew didn't make any sense. What do I have to lose... This is only my faith day and I really do notice a difference. I no longer feel depressed or worried about things that don't make sense and I finally feel like myself again. I am very hopeful that I am going to feel even better after a few weeks when the medication really gets in my system. I am thankful to god! This gave me hope! And peace of mind! Good Luck and hold on you all can do!

column2: racina, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was on 150 mgs for approx.7 months.It really helped me for some time.Started to get depressed again,shakes,fog like symtoms. decided to wean down ..try a different med. getting off this medication has been the hardest yet.I am now down to 37.5 mgs. column2: You Will Get Through This!, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This medication is far better than ciprolex or celexa.  I recommend doctors to go straight to this medication.  I also recommend getting th patient off sleep-aids if they are on them, asap! The reason is sandoz-buproprion or trazadone or panaxil etc. tends to be the culprit for the bad side-effects.  The patient needs to sleep, but might feel miserable and totally ineffective on them. As soon as they can sleep four hours or more regularly on their own, they need to get off the sleep-aids so they can see the effects of Effexor -XR working faster.  I have taken up to 262.5mg for over a year. There is not any problem with a higher suggested does as long as the patient is monitored every week in the increase phases. Even two times a week if they are a high risk patient.  Effexor is freedom that I haven't felt in years and I would not be here without it.  If you need it, take it!  If you had a malignant tumor, remove it! Same thing. Get proactive, take care of your depression, and get on with a normal happy life! Good Luck to you in your journey.

I have spoken with a few people about it and I might have to go to an actual detox facility if I want to get off of it all together. I have had issues with my insurance not wanting to cover this medicine and it has been a hassle since I started taking it.  If it didn't treat my depression at the same time I would not take it.  Definitely be causious is your doctor recommends it or if you are thinking about taking it.

Nausea, dizziness, incredible tiredness, massive emotional roller coaster, terrifying dreams, etc... there are days I feel so sick I can't get out of bed.  I am glad Effexor works for some but don't feel the physical side effects are worth it for me.  I would recommend EXTREME CAUTION to anyone considering this med as an option.  I stayed on a relatively low dose (75mg), as well and still had this many problems with it.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took a small dose (75mg) of Effexor, but for only a month. I heard a lot of bad things about it, but decided to go ahead and try it. The beginning was hard because of the side effects, (couldn't sleep, felt sick to my stomach, jaw clinching) I started out at 37.5mg, but after about 7-10 days moved to 75mg. As soon as I started the 75mg dose, I lost complete desire for sex and could not have an orgasm. That was it for me. I then decided to ween myself off of it. Again, read many bad things about going off the drug. I fortunately didn't have too many problems. I decreased my dose to 37.5 mg for a week from the 75 and experienced a little clinching of the jaw and maybe a little light-headedness. I'm now 4 days off completely. The only thing I notice is I'm having trouble sleeping at night. I am sure this will wear off soon. The good thing, my sexual desire is back. So overall the dug may have been fine if it didn't have the sexual side effect, and the weening off was fine as well. I may not have had any problems because I was on a low dose and only on the drug for a month. It's worth a try if you are wondering if it'll work for you. But if it doesn't, then I recommend going off of it sooner than later. PS. I read to take Fish Oil supplements and Super B complex while weening off, which I did. Hope this helps....

column2: maggien1031, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Bipolar people have enough mood swings. This drug, if it's not taken at a specific time every day, can send you into a violent manic tailspin, and no matter how much you know what you're doing is crazy, you can't stop it. If you have a sleep disorder, and cannot be sure of the exact time you take your meds, this drug is a death wish. It nearly cost me a husband, and my son, because this drug didn't help with my depression, and trying to come off of 300mg is a long process, and a dangerous one. I was suicidal, more so than ever, on this drug, and when I spoke to other members of my family, and friends, that took effexor xr, no one had anything good to say, whether they took 37.5 mg, or 300mg. Coming off XR, I had to lock myself in my bedroom, and pray that I wouldn't flip out because I was seriously scared of myself, and couldn't control my mood swings. This drug has done more harm than good in everyone that I've talked to.  DANGEROUS

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: The side effects of this drug were extreme for me. For the first few months I yawned constantly, never feeling like I was getting enough oxygen. The whole time that I was taking the meds I was tortured by nightmares that were not typical of any dreams that I'd ever had before. All of this I dealt with for the 1 1/2 years that I was on Effexor, but I feel compelled to tell my story of trying to ease off of the drug. I found the experience terrifying. I became instantly sad and angry. I also had "brain zaps" as I called them for several weeks. I could feel electrical shocks in my brain and legs and feet. I also had this strange sensation of being able to hear very loudly and feel my eyes moving. It all sounds silly, but was very scarey at the time. I started doing some research online, and found countless similar testimonials. Some people claimed that these 'Zaps' never went away. I was NEVER warned about any of this, and feel very betrayed by both my doctor and the drug industry. I suggest to anyone starting this med to be prepared.

My doctor switched me to Pristiq - not quite as effective, but so far, none of the side effects like Effexor. Effexor just more effective on my depression and anxiety. I was about to file for divorce and quit my job - all in that week I was off Effexor.  Not good to quit "cold turkey!"

column2: whitefeatherliz, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was placed on Effexor XR for Fibromyalgia and associated issues in Sept 2008. I started with 37.5 mg and worked my way to 75mg by Nov 2008. For the most part this medication worked for the pain and anxiety issues that come with Fibro... though the side effects were somewhat bothersome; hot flashes and sweating, my blood preasure became elevated requiring another med to lower it, I felt more tired than I did without the medication, and lacked motivation to do much of anything. I experienced dry mouth, dizzyness and stomach upset for the first several months then these subsided. I found this medication also caused me to become winded very easily, caused heart palpitations and muscle weakness when trying to walk any distance that would be part of everyday activities such as grocery shopping. I admit I do feel this med helped with mood and anxiety levels, since I have had to deal with serious family issues (my daughter was raped, and has been suicidal since the attack). I was able to calmly handle every aspect of the incident with great calm and focus. My reason for coming off the medication is because I am currently participating in a drug research program for Milnasipran so I had to detox off the effexor before starting the program / research. The worst part about the effexor was the coming off phase. The withdrawl from this medication was horiffic! My doctor advised me that because I was on a low dosage for a short period of time I could go cold turkey when coming off the med. I experienced terrible headaches, and zaps (the only way I can explain the effects my brain felt if I would move my head or eyes) this lasted for about 2 wks, I also was very ill; nausiated, diahrea, terrible body tremors, cold chills, and mood swings. All of these detox withdrawl symptoms I was advised can be normal. My brain (the zaps and headaches) was reacting to not having the chemicals that effexor balances out. Overall I believe this med works but I would not go back on it if I had to.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

PCPs don't know enough especially if you need to use more than one medication or an atypical dosage.  I wasted 8 years felling "good enough" but it wasn't!

column2: ANGELA,  Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: In the short term, Effexor XR was very effective in treating my depression and anxiety.  However, after being on this med for 8 months, I gained 35-40 lbs! The weight gain was not immediate, it just sneaks up on you.  There was abolutely no weight gain for the first 3 months or so, but then I noticed gaining a few pounds here and there and my clothes became tighter.  Even though I had not changed my eating habits at all, I was gaining weight!  I went from a size 8 to a size 12.  At that point, Effexor became counter-productive for me since the weight gain really depressed me.  I went off of it last week (cold turkey) and I've lost 4 lbs.  Luckily, I've had no withdrawal symptoms (even though you are not supposed to go cold turkey).  In summary, I guess for the short term (3 months or less), Effexor XR is great, but I would never EVER take it longer than that due to the weight gain.

column2: Jackey, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Effexor for 6 years for anxiety/depression. The Effexor got me out of a hell hole. But for the last year, I have been experiencing advancing blurriness, aggitation and finally jaundice. Because of my moods going up and down, I thought and also my psychiatrist thought that I was bipolar so he put me on Lamictal.I couldn't tolerate this med. because it caused severe joint pain. I had blood work checked last March and the results were all normal except for my cholesterol and triglycerides were  elevated. These are side effects of Effexor XR. I wish I had read all this information when all the symptoms started happening to my body. I should have gone on the computer and read all the side effects instead of being naive. I questioned my psychiatrist and he thought that I was rationalizing too much between an elevated blood pressure and an increase with my aggitation. (Jee, I am not bipolar after all). I guess I was right and he was definately wrong. Even though we have "mental issues", we should take all the changes in our behavior seriously after we are put on these medications. Our chemical imbalances lead us to take these chemicals. I have been off the med for almost 2 weeks after cutting myself down (I work in a doctor's office) and the main withdrawal was dizziness and I had to really concentrate on what I was saying. I feel great right now, no depression or anxiety. I hope and pray I remain this way and I hope that everyone pays attention to each and every day while on this med. Keep a diary.

column9: Hello  I hope my input will help someone who is suffering from Panic Disorder which can be debilitating when gone untreated. column2: Navajo62, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Before taking Effexor XR, I suffered from severe panic attacks, agorophobia, and had generalized anxiety disorder.  First I tried Zoloft, which made me feel horrible and I would literally wake up in the middle of the night having panic attacks.  After starting Effexor XR (give it a chance for your body to adjust to the medication, about a month) I have not had a major panic attack in years!  NOT ONE.  Started on 37.5 mg for a few weeks, then moved up to 75, the to 150, and took 225 mg for a few years.  You will have decreased energy, increased sweating, and lucid dreams.  All of these went away for me after using it for a few months.  When my dose was being increased, the symptoms would return for a week or so.  Not for high BP patients.Wean slowly...slower than you think.  I've been weaning for months now and have had great success.  DO NOT CUT YOUR DOSES IN HALF when trying to get off the med.  Instead, go down by 37.5 mg each month or so.  Seems conservative, but the side effects aren't as severe.  Unfortunately, this med is outrageously expensive.  I was paying as much as $240 a month at one point (with excellent insurance).  No generic!  When I missed a dose, I also paid the price.  Your head feels very "swimmy".  Light and sound was almost unbearable.  Take it in the morning with a light breakfast to curb insomnia in the evening.  Effexor XR has honestly changed my life.  I can leave my house, drive, be a good mom, and maintain healthy relationships again.  Hang in there!

column2: brunswickmom, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have taken Cymbalta and gained 35 lbs., went on Celexa and it did not work, now I'm on Effexor and experiencing the WORST side effects ever! Effexor has helped with anxiety attacks and mood swings, but the side effects are unbearable, and are 10 times worse if I don't take it at the EXACT same time everyday. Horrible nightmares, chronic constipation, dizziness, headaches and TOTAL loss of sex drive. If you are considering this drug, PLEASE think twice and talk to your doctor about other treatment options. I hope to ween myself off soon, but I'll need lots of help, this is a VERY powerful drug.

column2: sborror, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Effexor XR for 3 months now.  I have taken Cymbalta and Buspar and neither of them have worked as well as this. My dr. said that I could easily go to 75 mg a day, since that is the usual dose but I feel like this works for me.  At least for now.  I still have minor anxiety but nothing like I had before.  I have missed a dose now and then and when I do my biggest complaint is nightmares.  I realize when I decide to stop taking Effexor that I will experience awful side effects, but I think all medications have this.  When I went off of Cymbalta (took it for 6 months) I had brain zaps, dizziness, and other terrible symptoms that took a few months to get through.  But I did get through it.  This works for me now and I will continue to use it as long as I feel the need.  If your dr. recommends it, try it to see if it right for you.

column2: Ashbug20, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder, Anxiety/Panic Disorder, Agoraphobia and Emetophobia when I was 16 years old, even though these problems have been going on since I was about 11. For the first 2 years or so, it helped. I was able to leave the house and do the things I used to do with ease. Then things started to change. Now I constantly have nausea, insomnia, tremors, brain zaps, vertigo (dizziness) and mood swings. I take it every other day, and I still have the same result. It has effected my job, I have more panic attacks, I am slowly starting to not be able to leave the house, and I seem to be more irritable after its been in my system. After I take it, I am miserable the whole day. I can't eat, sleep, function, I feel like a zombie.When I don't take it, I have severe brain zaps, I cry if someone looks at me cross-eyed, I become more violent, and I can't leave the house. Even going to the grocery store makes it worse.I've tried a wide range of medicine to help relieve some of these symptoms, and so far nothing has worked: Celexa, Paxil, Depakote, Wellbutrin, Gapabentin, Neurontin, Topamax, Klonopin, Seroquel.Mind you, I was around 17-18 during the time that I was taking all these, so it could have been my age, and maybe the fact that I had raging hormones and "nothing worked". I don't have health insurance, so it's been quite hard for me to change medications, so I've stuck to this medication. Why? I have no idea. All I do know is that I need to get on something different. It doesn't seem to help me anymore, only make things worse. If anyone has any suggestions, please let me know. It would really help me out a lot. I just want my life back.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: It is an easy drug to use, just swallow it once a day. I have been on it for 12 years. I've tried to self wean myself off of it but can't.  The original prescribing doctor left the state six months after putting me on it but said it would only take a year for me to stablize emotionally and be taken off of it. Since going on it I have been diagnosed with Disassociative Personality Disorder; I have also become an alcoholic. When I told my doctor how much I drank, he told me I really shouldn't do that any more. I am suicidal but benefit from the personality disorder since part of me remains the caretaker of human beings and animals and birds that I have been for my whole life. My brother shot his rifle at me because I had refused to let him molest me at less than 9 years of age, my father both sexually assualted and abused me at an early age and also told me that I should have been killed as a defective being; my mother told me from an early age that as the second born twin I would have been killed at birth had I been born in Africa. (note: I'm not African). I thought Effexor RX would help me get through a difficult stage as a government whistle blower. Instead I am addicted to it and lorazapan and alcohol. If I didn't have the ability and opportunity to care for beings and creatures less fortunate, I would have left this world.  No, I don't think any medicene that requires taking it for 12 years and with no end in sight is good. Treating a symptom does not treat the person or the cause.  And anyone on these meds should realize that most medical studies only look at the complications of usage for 6 months or less. The analytical side of me tells me that there is something very wrong in an advanced society that perpetuates drug usage rather than helping individuals to overcome emotional trauma.

column2: mpenkava, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I am currently taking Effexor XR, and I have been taking it for the past 3-4 years (at least). I became depressed early in High School when I underwent extensive back surgery and my parents got a divorce. These two events happened simultaneously, and my father falsely blamed me for the divorce. This led to my severe depression and self-hatred. I convinced my father to let me talk to my General Practitioner about depression, because he doesn't believe in "Shrinks." After trying many other antidepressants (Prozac, Lexapro, Elavil, and others), my GP decided to start me on Effexor. I was 15 years old at the time. I was not made aware of the drug's short half-life, nor was I told of the extreme dependence I would develop. I have been taking a very high dose (300mg daily) since I began the drug, and I absolutely hate it. As far as my depression symptoms go, this drug has been very effective in controlling them. However, if I miss just one dose, I suffer extreme "brain shocks," dizziness, chills, shaking, and other withdrawal symptoms. I have talked with my GP about stopping this drug, but she will not assist me with it, because she believes I need to take it at least until I graduate from college. I am currently searching for a Psychiatrist who will understand this drug more thoroughly and who will help me break my addiction. I do not want to live my life dependent on a drug, and I wish I had never begun taking Effexor. Please consider VERY carefully the side effects and the dependence-causing qualities of this drug before you agree to take it. Also, be sure your doctor fully understands your condition. If you are suffering from a mental illness, speak to a Psychiatrist or Mental Therapist, not just your Family Doctor or General Practitioner. This medication is highly habit-forming. Please beware.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)

column2: Shellgbsn, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: So far so good but only been on this medication about 6 weeks for hot flashes and it has helped tremendously.  Started out noticing a reduction in the occurrence and intensity and now I am down to very few per "week" if any!  However, I am concerned for the withdrawals when I come off as I have read some nasty stories.

column2: anon, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I've taken several medications for recurrent severe depression over the last 15 years. My experience with Effexor has been the worst. I had been taking 150mg for about 3 months and felt better. The depression "broke through" again and my doc increased the dose to 300mg. I began to experience terrible side-effects: headaches, irritability and even though I do not drink alcohol I felt hung-over every morning. Called the doctor and started cutting back the dosage over a few weeks. Now that I am not taking the drug at all I am miserable. I cannot sleep at night, I feel anxious, I'm experiencing what others have described as "brain shivers" and I just feel like my brain is not working properly. I'm having a lot of short-term memory problems too. It's the worst withdrawal I've ever experienced. I wish I had learned more about this drug before I began taking it. Any benefit I had during the first 3 months do not outweigh the side-effects and horrible withdrawal. This is a drug of last resort. Use with caution.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking this medicine in 1999 and had no side effects ever. I got off of it in 2005 and was fine after weaning off for just a week from 75 mg to 35mg to nothing. Then I got pregnant and had my daughter in 2007 and I was fine for like three months, then started to have anxiety. I went back on effexor. I started with 150 mg then went to 75 4 months later. I did fine ecxept I was tired alot. Then about six months after that, only being on it less then a year, I tried to get off it. I took 35mg for 2 weeks and was fine. Then boom, it just hit me. This medicine is a nightmare to get off of. I had severe nausea, brain zaps, dizziness,crying,fear.etc. I just tried to get off it again in Nov 2008 with no sucess. Sme thing happened. I dont know why I was ok getting off it in 2005 but not now. Why is it different? It has helped me alot with anxiety, but it is horrible to get off. The withdrawls are unbearable. I would not recommend this medicine to anyone!!!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

I prefer to take at night, I sleep better-altho the doc says that is highly unusual. If I miss a dose, I will get a severe headache, occasionally they turn into migraines. so I take my meds. I like that I haven't needed to "readjust" or that the meds stop working. 3 yrs vs. 3 months is awesome!

column2: karenhillisme, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: If you plan on taking this medication for the rest of your life, it will probably work to help with depression.  I took it for 2 years and then found out that I was pregnant and my OB asked me to quit cold turkey and I was literally suicidal because of the terrible, unexplainable side effects.  I felt bewildered, like my head wasn't on right, random sweating rages, and other things that aren't describable unless you have to go through it.  I saw my OB and he allowed me to wean myself off of the medication, but my life was a living hell for about a month.  Fortunately I was finally off of it totally and my baby (now 2) is happy and healthy.  I am on celexa now, which works as good or better than the effexor.  I can honestly say that time was the worst time i my life.

column2: mommyof3girls, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Ive taken Lexapro for 3 years but had to change due to my insurance co so my dr gave me effexor xr.  This medication had been horrible for me, after taking it for two weeks my blood pressure went through the roof (with no previous bp problems) and I got terrible migraines.  When I stopped taking it the withdrawls were horrific!! Ive never had to withdraw from any medication and never want to feel that again.  So for now I either deal with high bp and migraines OR my head feeling foggy and tingling that feels like electrical shocks in my head, my lips and my hands.  Which one is better? Neither!  I think this drug should be taken off the market for good! I just hope to feel better soon!

column2: roper, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: This is a very dangerous drug which should not be used lightly.  My experience was that it was not very effective for treating the symptoms of depression, and once I made the decision with my doctor to discontinue use, the side effects of withdrawal were absolutely unbearable. It took almost a year to come off the drug with very small reductions in dosage because any larger reductions caused me to not be able to function properly. Even going from the smallest available dose (37.5 mg) to nothing was almost impossible - I had to break the capsules apart and count out the little pellets inside to make smaller reductions in dose. The doctor's suggestion to take 37.5 mg every other day was not helpful - it just meant that the "day off" was terrible. Please, please consider the severe side effects of this drug before using it. It may be able to help you, but if it doesn't, you will pay a very high price for taking it.

This stuff worked great for me for three years but when it came time to get off of it,  well lets just say  YIKES!!!!  i have been having brain zaps and depersonalization for 4 months. column2: Lisa Pooh, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This medication was very hard on me. Everytime I would move my body and head I would get a "shock" that would go up to the top of my head like it was an electrical shock. I felt as if my brain was moving. Sounds scarey, you should feel it to experience it. How can any company make this pill for any human being is just cruel. I think if the doctors would take this pill for 1 month and get off of the pill they would not recommend this pill for nobody! This pill is the most physical addicting pill I have ever been on and highly recommend that no one to take this pill. It made me have sucidial thoughts and actually did overdose and was put in rehab different times over this medication. I went off this pill with out my doctor's permission because I didn't want this in my system anymore. I feel so much better now then when I was taking that medication. I have been off Effexor for now over 2 years. Thank God for taking this in my own hands and getting off this nasty medication. Xanax is much better for me and I only take it when I need it not like the Effexor. Plus I have no side effects with Xanax. I hope that I could help someone with this and encourage people not to attempt to take Effexor. This pill will ruin your life if you stay on it. I know too many other people who went thru the same as I with Effexor.

column9: I started w/75mg for depression and anxiety, it helped almost immediately. 3 years later, I felt that it was not working any longer. column9: This medication was first prescribed for me in 1999, after an old spinal injury flared up. From the very beginning The medication did exactly what it's supposed to do. I started out taking the Effexor XR at a very low dose and was "built up" to the 150 mg a day,that I've taken for so long. About 4 years ago the medication was increased to 150 mg Am & 150 mg PM. About 1 year ago I noticed that the medication didn't seem to be working as effectively as it always had. So, about 8 months ago, my Dr added Wellbutrin SR 150 mg to my medications. I don't take the wellbutrin every day, just on those days that I feel is gonna be a really bad day. On those days I take 150 mg Effexor XR & 150 mg Wellbutrin SR AM and if I feel that I need it I take it the same way at night, before I go to bed. Over all The medication has worked very well for me.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This is a follow up to my 11/25/2008 1:57:57PM coments (read it first if you haven't already). I've just finished my second month of withdrawl down from 75mg to 0 mg of effexor. The last 4 or 5 days have turned out to be worse than any other. A lot of back and forth feelings of neverousness and calmness (it's more like my nerves are becoming more active, in a very unconfortable way, and directly reacting to the change in my body chemistry (Effexor withdrawl?). These nerveous reactions  do not seem to be related to my state of mind or thought process they just change directions at ramdom. There are periods when my nervious system calms down and I feel just fine. I have to admit the last few days (not counting today) I all most gave up, I believe the Effexor web site said it takes up to 3 months to clear out of your system so I plan to ride out the whole 3 months and decide then.On one hand if I go back on the effexor I face nite terrors (screaming in my sleep, diving out of bed, waking up with bumps and bruses and having little or no memory of the event)(my wife and kids tell me about it in the morning) (my wife sleeps in a different bed room so she avoids any injury). On effexor, I have no memory of having any normal dreams. To be honest I love having  normal dreams (not nightmares) over the past two months, since I've been off effexor. I'm done for now and need to take a break.

column2: wagirl, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking Effexor 2 years ago to treat severe depression and anxiety with heart palpitations.  My doc also put me on atenolol to control the palpitations, which is a nice combo because it reduces your blood pressure and prevents migraines.    After a year I felt better, like many of you who complained about wanting to get off it, and slowly tapered off.  What I have learned in the last year of horrible depression trying to do it "on my own" with diet, exercise, counseling, and the atenolol - is that going off was a horrible mistake.  I was feeling better BECAUSE of the Effexor XR.  I stopped working out, gardening, doing the things I love this year.  I am now back on it and committed to staying on it for at least two years straight this time.  I had tried Prozac, Celexa, Wellbutrin before with limited results on my depression and increased anxiety.  Effexor XR is the only one that has really helped both my depression and anxiety at the same time.  Within 24 hrs of starting it again, I already feel calmer, happier, more hopeful and at peace.  Life seems worth living and I am thankful for everyone in my life again too instead of ready to walk away from them all, lock myself in a hotel room, and cry for a few months like I was before I started it again.  Yes, decreased libido, difficulty achieving orgasm, don't drink more than one alcoholic drink or you will be sick and have the worst migraines and nausea ever, vivid dreams and some difficulty sleeping.  Overall, it has definitely been worth it. Definitely not a "starter" antidepressant, but it can be very effective when others don't work for you.  I recommend the XR version over the others to reduce side effects.  I am a therapist myself and sometimes people have biological causes of depressions that need something strong like this.  Commit to taking this one if you need it, and withdraw VERY slowly.  It can save lives.  It did mine.

column9: I was on Effexor XR before and weaned myself off with less trouble than getting off Paxil, but still hated the brain zaps.  I found gradually lowering the dose helps you get off. I could not tolerate the psychotic (sp) meds side effects and my depression was kicking in (attempted suicide twice) so doc put me back on Effexor.  (Got off due to sexual side effects) Still hate the side effects, but would rather be happy and more healthy.  All is heriditary, lucky me!  So, I am on Effexor XR for depression and anxiety, another anxiety medication, and adderal for my ADHD.  So far, I feel okay, some shakes here and there, especially if I forget to eat since both meds decrease appetite.  Daugther (yes, it got passed down from my dad, to me, to by girls) is on prozac and seems to help with her high anxiety level and anger/depression.  Took her off Adderal after she became moody and irratable on it.  Would definately recommend finding which meds work for you.  Life is too short to spend it depressed and living with anxiety and panic attacks.  There is hope.  Good luck to all and God bless!

column9: I started having panic attacks 7 years ago. I tried Zoloft, and Celexa and now Effexor XR. The Effexor XR works the best for me for panic attacks.  I have to take the pill with food or it will make me queasy. I am tired and have very vivid dreams. My main complaint is that I am unable to achieve an orgasm. I know that it is the Effexor XR, because I never had a problem before, and a few months back I weened off the Effexor XR for a few months and was immediately able to achieve an orgasm.  But then I had to start taking it again because I started having panic attacks.  My Dr. suggested Lexapro - it supposedly has less sexual side effects, but I am happy with Effexor XR for the effectiveness on the panic attacks.  My regular life is fairly normal, but my sex life is the pits!  I wish I could find a medicine without the sexual side effects, but every medicine effects everyone differently.

I returned to the Dr. She INCREASED the dosage to 150MG and I was miserable, still hot flashing and my face began breaking out, making me look like some kind of meth junkie.My face was constantly breaking out after being on the lower dose but now I was a PIZZA FACE. I began to decrease the dosage and then I stopped the  madness by stopping the drug. I am getting dizzy and have a hard time concentrating BUT my face started clearing up in three days after stopping. I will put up with the Flashes and  the dizziness but never will I go back on this CRAP for HOT FLASHES. My next letter is going to be to the FDA. This is the only medication I was on and I have no other illnesses so the drug companies and my own DR. cannot  say it was a reaction to  anything else.
