column2: Geebee, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Laid off after 36 yrs, I could barely function due to depression.  Other drugs made me groggy.  Effexor worked within a few days. Until this year, I managed on only 37.5 mg. Major life stresses increased it to 75 mg; working very well.  I have been off and on it for over 5 years - BUT - you cannot just stop taking it - or any anti-depressant! You have to taper the dosage slowly - which I have done several times over the years and have had no side effects or withdrawal.  I was shocked to see the comments where people "forgot" to take it, or didn't get a refill.  Very dangerous to fool around with medications and therefore, your health. Talk to your doctor!

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I started at 350mg after the intial month of side effects it worked well for Anxiety, but made sleeping difficult and dreams or at least remembering dreams became nonexistent. I lost all ability to have a spontaneous erection and performance on command was extremely difficult. About 1 year ago I successfully attempted to decrease my dose down to 75 mg over several months with little side effects, my sexuall function improved as I decreased the dose. When I tried to advance from 75mg down to 37.5mg I felt a mild form of intermitant Anxiety, started to have/remember  nightmarish dreams and desided to regroup at 75mg for several more months. At the begining of November 08 I decided to go from 75mg to 0. After a nite or two I started to have/remember my dreams and still do after about 30 days no nightmares that I can recall and I 've had my first natural spontaneous erection since starting effexor 5 years ago. The down sides: the first 8 to 10 days I was extremely emotional I mean I cried at sad car tunes, movies it was embarrassing but that went away after 10 days: I also had unusual sounds in my head (kinda hard to describe WHAAA Whaaa?)that disapeared after 10 days also. The last few days (27th to 29th I've started to have(unprompted by any events) intermittent,very mild anxiety, alternating with spells of peace and calm and last for several minuntes each and then disapate. I don't know how long withdrawal last, any feed back on that? Some people have mentioned it takes months. I hope not.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: This drug worked great (much better than other antidepressants) for me for a few years, then the good effects seemed to wear off.  Sexual side effects were awful also.Also, this is not a scientific claim at all, but I and others have noticed that it seems to make you smoke a LOT more (if you smoke already)- I tried another bout w/ this drug recently and it didn't work how it did the first time - still made me smoke like a fiend though, and maybe even made me crave alcohol more, too.  This drug is VERY hard to get off of.  I had the "brain shivers" for several MONTHS after reaching a 0 dose after tapering down off of it as slowly as possible. Looking back on this drug, considering its withdrawal symptoms and the fact that it didn't feel the same when I "retried" it is that I sort of felt/feel nervous that it changed my brain or something.  I feel like I am not nearly as smart/quick as I was before I ever took it.  I can't say that this drug caused that, but it seems to be the determining factor.  So, I would say that anyone should be careful taking this drug b/c it is very powerful.  It can help a lot, but it is very easy to become dependent on, and might end up changing you.  It's not a good first choice for folks who just need "a little help getting through the holidays" or need a little help after a bad event.  It is more appropriate (in my opinion) for someone willing and able to continue w/ it (if it works well) for chronic/serious depression.

Apparently, side effects are relatively rare with this medication, but I got it all and then some...Couldn't sleep, constantly clenching and grinding teeth, shaking, crying, severely dilated pupils to the point where my eyes hurt and I couldn't see. Takes about a month for the meds to work, but only eight hours to get the side effects. I understand it works for a lot of people, but obviously not me. I'm on zoloft now and that is working much better for me.

column2: M, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have suffered from Chronic Depression, Panic Disorder, and Social Anxiety for a very long time now and it has only gotten worse over the years. Effexor has worked the best of any drug I have tried in regards to Depression and Panic treatment. I am now up to 225mg per day, and I think I found my correct dosage. It has been months since I have experienced any panic attacks, and severe depression bouts are virtually gone as well. If you have started this medication, be sure to converse with your doctor frequently to find the dose that is best for you. Also, this is an SNRI drug- which means it works for serotonin and norepinephran- but, the benefits of norepinephran cannot be seen at a low dose; if you stop increasing at an early stage, you may as well be taking an ordinary SSRI like Zoloft, etc.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I took this medication for anxiety and depression, but mostly for anxiety. During my teen years it helped me concentrate in class as well. I started taking it at age 17 and recently stopped it due to pregnancy. Tapering off of it was not hard for me and I notice only slight physical symptoms of anxiety currently. (Since I learned how to cope without the medicine) It is category C for pregnancy so I decided to stop using it because the baby would be exposed to it. I believe it is worth it for my child's brain to function normally while in the womb. I had no side effects. The extended release capsules were a 'life saver' compared to the generic venlafaxin because the generic I had to take twice a day and I could not sleep; it disrupted my daily life. I tried 3 brands before this one and after 3-4 years of switching my doctor gave me this and it along with counseling helped me to learn to cope with life in a healthy way. My mother takes the same brand and it works for both of us better than any other brand. I keep suggesting it to my sister since I think depression could be hereditary in our family. I would recommend this medicine to anyone. I did not feel like it took over my mood or personality, it only allowed me to try to function normally and get my life back on track in a positive way.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor has saved my life. Before I was put on this, I was a complete mess-- attempting sucicide frequently, self-injuring to the point of needing stitches regularly, starving myself, multiple hospitalizations. During my very last hospitalization over a year ago, I was taken off all of my meds (high doses of Abilify, Seroquel, Lamictal, Trazadone, Prozac, Lithium, and Inderal) and put on Effexor. I do not remember the early days on Effexor (that period is kind of blurry, and I was withdrawing from the other medications), but I have been on Effexor ever since. I have had one dose increase, but now at 225 mg, I am doing amazing. I realize the poteniality of life and the little wonders each person has inside. This medication has really helped keep the depression at bay and allowed me to re-enter my life.

column9: To me, this drug has been beyond helpful.  Before deciding to finally treat my depression and hopefully get rid of it once and for all, I tried Paxil with limited response. Now 5 days into cold turkey and I am totally exhausted! My husband has had to wake me up out of horrible, fitful nightmares 4/5 of those nights, some only to continue when I fall asleep again. Mornings~ my body is sore from my minds' activities; running from..., inability to scream, though vocal(he says), flailing of arms and legs, night sweats, and just total mind and body exhaustion from the night's events. I have just left a message with my GP, after finding these posts, to see if he can help me to detox from this OR modify my rx.  My pain mgt. doctor doesn't like prescribing antidepressants anyway, nor did he even remember doing so, although he has been doing so for 3 yrs. I feel I should've been warned about these sorts of things happening, tho I do know that cold turkey isn't usually the right way to get off any medication.

column9: Let me start by saying that in the begining this medicine was great, though it was alwayIs being upped.I lost weight I loved that part. but then I started having what was thought to be panic attacks. after severl months of these attacks I tried to stop taking this medicine. I called the drug co. myself and told them  what was going on, I asked how long these symptoms would last, they did not know. after many trips to the DR. and hospitals I was told that my so called panic attacks wern't panic they were mini siezures. any way I stayed off the meds and it was pure Hell for about 2 or 3 months. one thing that did help ease the dizziness ,vomiting ect... was the hospital gave me a script for motion sickness, I don't remember the name but you can ask your DR. column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was an alcoholic and became suicidal. After a overdose of prescription drugs and a ER hospital stay I entered a Live-In rehab for a week. My Dr. prescribed EFFEXOR (150mg) daily. That was 4 yrs. ago, I don't drink anymore, seeming to be better but not making my life better. I tried Double the dose but I felt very angry towards friends who said the wrong thing or extreme Road Rage. I have went back to 150mg on  my own, but yet to see a Dr. about this. I like to be calm but I feel like life is passing me by at this point. I either want to take drug and feel happier or not at all. I'm open to try a much larger dose but I'm afraid I might go crazy! I am a 62 year old female, lost 2 jobs in 2 yrs., unemployed at the present, no boyfriend since 1998, and a Breast Cancer survivor of 7 yrs. I used to have anxiety issues to the extreme, but those went away after cancer treatment. I credit Effexor for "evening me out", but I feel like I need something more. My original Dr. moved away last year and I don't think the one I have now is that good. But now, with no insurance and limited income, it's not easy to try out different things. I have gotten Effexor from Canada Drugs for 4 yrs. to be able to afford them, but now I'm going to the County for help on that this Nov. The medication works amazingly, but like a lot of other people have stated it's extremely hard on you if you stop or forget to take you medicine.  If she forgets a dose she suffers from severe headaches, dizziness/vertigo, irritability, sweating and sharp "lightning like" flashes going from her head to her toes.Please if you are attempting to stop taking this medication, do yourself a favor and speak to your doctor first.  I'm sure they'll be able to give you a good guideline about how to correctly stop taking it.  Otherwise prepare yourself for a tough journey if you're trying to go "cold turkey".

column2: Jules, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed an antidepressant called 'dothep' after my 1st baby was about 3mths old and I nearly shook her. They did NOTHING I was just really sad, and sleepy (not good with a new baby)I tried all sorts of things to make me feel a bit better, including exercise, acupuncture, herbal mixtures, smoking, counseling.  I think that Effexor was new on the market at the time and my Doc asked if I would like to give it a try which was about 10 years ago when my 1st child was nearly two, I couldn't believe the difference. I FINALLY felt 'alive' again, unfortunately when I fell pregnant with my 2nd one in 1998 the Doc took me off and put me on some other drug. I had terrible neck pain and low blood pressure - I even gave up smoking I felt so ill. When she was born I went straight back on the Effexor and have been on them ever since. In 2002 I had got myself down to 37.2mg and doing alot of exercise I never felt any withdrawal side effects. I then hit a 'BIG WALL' in my life and had to get the dose put back up, but then baby #3 decided to come along, Doc said stay on my Effexor since I'd been on it for so long - he didn't like my side effects from last pregnancy either.I am currently on 150mg which I take every morning. If I don't take it by 1pm my fingertips go all tingly and funny and I soon remember, the longest that I have gone without is three days and I didn't know that I had forgotten them. Over the years my doses have varied, alot has to do with what's happening in my life.I have been on these with drinking alcohol, and that was not too good, I now just have them every day and I find that even though life's little tests can make me feel like it is all up and down, I know that the Effexor is keeping me on an even keel and I believe that I am staying pretty level in my day to day feelings, and not going to extremes, as I had previously experienced.I hope this review helps someone else, as I believe that you can't just 'solve' depression/anxiety in a few months.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: To those saying Effexor should be removed from the market, let's be fair - different meds work in different ways for different people. It is your (along with your doctor's) responsibility to research new medications before starting to put them into your body. My doctor warned me about the side effects and let me make the decision to try Effexor to determine if the benefits outweigh the detriments. I have experienced increased sweating (I knew that to be a possible side effect) as well as the withdrawal symptoms many have described ("electrical storm in the head", dizziness, etc.) but luckily, I knew what to expect and the effects were manageable. It is absolutely IMPERATIVE that you discuss ramping the dosage up/down when you start/stop Effexor XR. If your health care provider does not mention the possible withdrawal symptoms associated with missing a dosage or stopping Effexor "cold turkey", they do not know enough about this medication to be prescribing it. If this medication does not work for you (give it 6-10 weeks for full effect), taper the dosage and get off - try something else. I only remain on Effexor because it works to manage my depression. As common sense would indicate, do not stay on this medication if the benefits do not outweigh the side effects. The withdrawal symptoms will be worse than any of the side effects you experience on Effexor, but they ARE temporary (so far as we know) and will go away after ~ one week. I have been on and off different dosages for years and can tell you that it's not a drug to put in your body unless you are aware of and understand the potential undesired effects.

column9: never take this drug. your body will become dependent on it and the withdrawl includes brain  zaps and brain shocks. i took it to calm down my migraines ,it  was prescribed by another doctor instead of my regular neurologist. i had to go back to the neurologists office because i thought i was having seizures. i gained sixy lbs that ive been fighting to loose. its a miserable drug with no redeeming qualities. and, it didnt help the condition.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This drug was the absolute worst medication I have ever been prescribed, and due to the fact that I have lupus, I've been prescribed plenty over the years. If I had a flare up, and slept for too long, therefore not taking my pill at the exact time every day, I had horrible mood swings that became progressively more violent, and I could not control them, even knowing that I was being outrageous. I had terrible headaches that rendered me useless at times. I felt suicidal, and it became increasingly worse. I became paranoid, and developed sleeping problems. Trying to come off of this dangerous drug was an equally terrifying experience. I was told that I couldn't start a different drug in the same "category" because of what these drugs-pain relieving antidepressants-are made of. And I just had to fight my way through it, tapering off from 300 mgs. daily. Luckily, a doctor prescribed depakote, and that has helped. 3 people in my family have been prescribed effexor at varying dosages through the years, from 37.5 mgs, to my 300 mgs., and not a single one of them has had a good thing to say about the experience. I would strongly recommend, if someone's dr prescribes them effexor, say NO and find a new dr.

column2: mslvr01, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor was the only medication that worked for me, I take 300Mg daily, however there is a price pay.  Specifically if I miss a dose I go through the WORST withdrawals.  I get nauseous, dizzy, sweaty, nervous.  It is torture.  I want to get off of it but I can`t.  Beware before you start this drug.  It works but it is hell to get off of.  I`ve been on it for 3.5 years.

column2: roxanne9, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: bravodingo, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I've been taking Effexor XR (75mg) for about 3-4 months now, and while I definitely noticed a change in my attitude (not nearly as many mood swings, etc.), the side effects were rough.  I often experienced nightmares, sleeplessness borderlining on insomnia, and inability to achieve orgasm.  In addition to this, I do NOT like the idea of possibly having to increase my dosage, making me even more dependant on a drug that I personally do not believe was necessary in the first place.  I have missed doses in the past, and experience even worse side-effects, i.e. these 'electric shocks' that everyone seems to mention, strong mood swings, and even worse cases of insomnia.  Noting this only helps reinforce my decision to stop taking this medication, as the side effects will eventually cease...the only question being - how long?  I last took this medication 48 hours ago, and the electric shock feeling is the worst of the bunch.

column2: SwetDreamsPance, 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Although Effexor worked wonders for me for years, after I moved out I was cut from my parents' insurance plan and could no longer afford treatment--and the withdrawal was insane. I was dizzy, had anxiety attacks, cried for no reason, was angry at everything, or verged on manic. These changes in mood were rapid and unexplainable...also felt hungry but threw up most everything I ate. I was tired and weak all the time and had disturbingly vivid dreams...it was enough to keep me from trying it again once I got insurance through my job. I dont want to be on it forever, but stopping is out of the question--the cons outweigh the pros with this med, I think.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started this a week ago. I haven't slept much all week. It's making my insomnia worse. My head feels numb and I've had a headache all week. I feel sick all the time and can't eat much. I've lost about 5lbs already. I get really shaky and my legs will involuntarily shake. I feel kind of numb.. I don't feel like me. But I'm not sad or mad much anymore.

column2: kchilds, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: FOR THOSE WHO STOPPED TAKING EFFEXOR XR:  I have now been off this medication for 4+ weeks.  I promised to keep up to date what my withdrawal symptoms were and how long they lasted.  ALL WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS ARE GONE!!!  It was THE MOST difficult thing I had ever gone through, but now I am ME again!!  I just want those suffering to know that there IS an end!!!!!  I went through a few weeks so sick to my stomach.  The body aches, sweating, twitching and SEVERE Muscle spasms lasted for about 4 weeks.  The muscle spasms STARTED after about two weeks of being off medication.  That was actually the worst of all.  I was taking Clonazapam to help with that, which it did.  Again, I just need for people to know that all the terrible withdrawal symptoms will end.  Don't start taking them again just because you can't take it.  TALK TO YOUR DOCTOR about what you can do and take to ease these symptoms.  I can never say how happy I am to finally be off Effexor XR.....  FOREVER!  I wish everyone on here the best, and hope that the information provided might help those looking for answers.Good luck to all!K. Childs

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Being ON Effexor wasn't so bad.  I had slight improvement in depression.  Had to go off of it because I wanted to get pregnant.  There are no words to describe the horrors of withdrawal.  It is horrendous.  I felt like I had the worst flu imaginable for 6 weeks.  And I went off of it very slowly for the 4 weeks prior to that.  I was vomiting, had vertigo, fever, exhausted, achy, literally unable to move a muscle without serious pain.  What saved me was that I got hold of a few non XR tablets of Effexor and I would take a very small bite (probably 5 mgs?) of it when I felt horrible.  That relieved my withdrawal for a few hours usually.  They don't make non XR anymore as far as I know but I would also call up the toll free Effexor line and scream at them whenever possible.  I would suggest that the company make the non-XR for this reason.

13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: i've suffered from depression through most of my childhood/teenage years and tried prozac which didn't help at ALL. this made a HUGE difference. the only thing i don't really like about it is when you don't take if for a few days, you get really nauseous and it feels like electric jolts are going through your body. but then again, it's kind of like a built in reminder to take your pills.

column2: lomi, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I've had a horrible experience with Effexor! This drug is not worth it!!!  I am in the process of quitting Effexor after about 1 year. While it did help at first with my depression and anxiety the withdrawal process is horrible! I did not receive any information about addiction/withdrawal from my doctor, pharmacist or the medication guide. According to the Effexor website this drug is not addictive - totally false! When I talked to my doctor about the lightheadedness I experienced each day as I would get close to the time to take the pills, she just said "oh that's odd you are so sensitive to it" and recommended that I take the pills at a different time. I also experienced extreme sleepiness daily. After slowly cutting down my dose over the last month I have now been off Effexor for 3 days. I am ok as long as I don't move my head or eyes which is impossible. I have a feeling somewhere between sea-sickness and electric shocks running through my brain. Combined with muscle aches and tension, nausea, insomnia and spontaneous crying I am not functional at this point. A nurse at my health provider told me today to expect these withdrawal symptoms to last at least one week. This experience has more than undone any good that Effexor has done for me. I am glad that the drug has helped some people, but i feel that it should be taken off the market. I'm afraid that what I'm experiencing now may be causing some damage to my brain that will come back to haunt me later. Although i have been diagnosed as dysthymic with several episodes of major depression since childhood, I am through with anti-depressants and all prescription drugs for now. My doctor had recommended that I try Cymbalta after getting off Effexor, but it reportedly also has strong withdrawal symptoms for many people. I don't want to go through this again. Don't risk your mental and physical health with Effexor!

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Good and bad experiences with Effexor. I was on this drug for about 2 yrs. I was on 75mg for one year and 150 the 2nd. It immediately helped with the depression/anxiety. It did affect my sleep, made me able to sleep an abnormal amount. Also, after waking I could wave my hand in front of my face and experience tracers, sometimes more intense than other times. One summer I went home from college and ran out of meds, withdrawal symptoms were intense!  Intense restlessness, weird vision, odd dizziness, mood swings, etc.  Mostly made my head feel strangely terrible and unlike it ever had before.  Resumed meds and returned to normal.  Now, I have been coming off the meds and have just fully come off them.  Withdrawal symptoms have been weird feeling in head, intense moods, lots of crying at one point, and now have been experiencing some stabbing pains in my torso that I am pretty sure have to do with the changes in meds. BASICALLY, this med can help but coming off is difficult and will make you experience things you never have before. Every person experiences it differently and lucky for me I think my case was not too bad.  Doctors should be educating their patients more thoroughly about this drug and it's effects.  This is a drug for mental conditions, and treating such a thing should not be treated lightly.  These are our lives we are dealing with.  Patients have the right to know more about what we are taking.

column9: To HAIM777.... You CAN DO IT!!!!!  You will have a rough time for a little while.  But, YOU WILL GET THROUGH IT!!!!!  I PROMISE! column2: haim777, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am so upset that I was ever prescribed this drug. Let me first say: It DOES work. My depression and especially my anxiety have been non-existent while taking. However, the withdrawal symptoms are THE WORSE EVER. Even if I was late taking a dose (I usually take in the morning) by the afternoon, I would be nauseus, BRAIN ZAPS, headache, and very weak. When I take my meds, it goes away. I hate what this has done to me. I think this drug really needs to be taken off the market. It may work for depression and anxiety but the price you pay is not worth it. There are  other ways to deal with depression and others meds that don't cause such horrible side effects. I've gained 30lbs in 8 mos. I just talked to my DR. 2 days ago and he's starting me on a plan to start weaning off. I am so scared because I've read the horror withdrawal stories. But I am so desperate to get off this drug, that I'm willing to deal with the symptoms. If you are thinking about taking this drug: DON'T DO IT!!!

column2: kchilds, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I am going to try and keep up with posting my withdrawal symptoms and how long they are lasting.  I hope this will be useful for others going through that hell.  Just returned from the doctor about my SEVERE muscle spasms.  I MEAN SEVERE!!!!  They started two days ago.  You can't sleep.  It HURTS!!!!!  :/  He put me on Clonazapam to ease that and said I may have to endure another week of this.  The headaches are going away.  I am no longer sick to my stomach all the time.  Sweating has eased up a lot.  AllI can say is, if you are trying to stop taking this medication, you will need to endure some awful side effects.  DO NOT GIVE IN and start taking them again.  It will be hard, but it will end.I hope and pray someone will find some confort with this information.  Again, you are not alone and it WILL go away.  I will post again once I am ME again.  I just wish this information was available when I first tried to get off it!!!!Good luck to everyone!!!!

column2: kchilds, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: First, I wish that people would state if they are male or female while posting these comments.  I think the side effects are different in males and females. Effexor XR DID help with my depression and anxiety, BUT, I did GAIN WEIGHT!!!  I went from 120 pounds to almost 160 in a very short time frame.  THAT made me more depressed.  I was not eating a lot.  So while the medication did help make me feel better and ease my anxiety attacks, I did suffer from weight gain and dry mouth.  Due to losing my job, no insurance and no money, I have been OFF Effexor XR for 10 days now.  THIS IS THE WORST I HAVE EVER FELT IN MY LIFE!!!!.  My Doctor DID NOT tell me about the side effects of coming off Effxor XR.  I have been throwing up constantly, dizzy all the time, flu like symptoms, can't sleep, severe body aches.........  It is amazing how horrible the withdrawal symptoms are.  I just want others to know that they are NOT CRAZY and are NOT ALONE.  I have been trying to find out how long this will last to no avail.  I feel suicidal because I do not know what to do to ease these symptoms, but I WILL NEVER GO BACK to Effexor XR....EVER!!!!!  DO NOT TAKE unless you intend to be on it for a LONG time and understand all possible side effects.

column2: Home of cowboys, a paradise, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Didn't feel much when I started with 75 mg. Just tried to come off it but it wouldn't let me,even had to call the Ambulance to go to hospital and spent a night there due to the symptomsI experienced.I had to go back on it.Slowly reduced to 37.5 mg then now I open up the capsule and divide them further more to around 18 mg because I am pregnant and am so concerned to what effect it can have on unborn. I wish I wean off it and wish there was some help availabe to quickly come off it. Doctors should explain more on side effects and symptomps when starting and weaning off and should be mentioned on the packs as well.

column2: bankermom, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Effexor XR 75 mg for about 2 years. Finally decided to wean off by taking the 1/2 dose (37 mg) for 3 weeks. Still had horrible withdrawal symptoms after stopping that for only a day and a half: dizziness, nausea, headache, buzzing in head, diarrhea. My husband had the idea to open the capsule and divide up the medicine even further, so it's an even more gradual modification than stopping the 37 mg. Just sprinkle it on applesauce, but don't crunch or chew. I've been on approx. 25 mg. for about 5 days now. Getting ready to lower that even more. The side effects are not nearly as bad. Still get a bit of headache, dizziness, and nausea after about 12 hours, but it's much more tolerable. I'm hoping this will be an easier way to stop completely. I'll know more in another week or so. Good luck to everyone.

column9: I have been on this med for almost 2 years.It has helped me so much- it is worth the tiredness & cost.At one point, I was weaned off of the med b/c I didn't want to be on any pills anymore and since my doctor took my weaning VERY SLOWLY I did NOT have any withdrawal symptoms. column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I guess the fact that a drug doesn't work on some individuals doesn't make it a BAD or DANGEROUS drug then, when it DOES help or work on some others. I've read up the reviews on most antidepressants & can see that almost everyone experiences side-effects & withdrawal symptoms - some none, some mild, & others severe. They say "No pain no gain."Doctors aren't know-all, so it's best if one does some research on their own & not rely fully on their doctor for info. One has to weigh the pros. & cons. of taking a drug themselves, not getting discouraged by others' unpleasant experiences. For example, before taking Effexor, I was sad 24/7. I would curl up in bed whole day, re-playing hurtful & unpleasant memories from past,& getting so worked up over them (angry/sad) all over again. I kept thinking of all sorts of sad things & just cried & cried. I wanted my husband to stay with me all the time; I was so demanding. I didn't want to go out or do anything. My world was so dark & gloomy. I even got suicidal, thinking of quick & painless ways to die. Everything seemed hopeless, like I was never going to get better, ever. I just wanted to die. Or I believed I was seriously going insane. Now, although Effexor mostly makes me so drowsy & fatigued & causes some other inconveniences, I'd rather suffer from these for a while than go back to the miserable & horrifying state I was in, which was a whole lot more difficult for others to deal with.One last thing, if you can afford it, try counseling by a psychologist. It sped up my recovery by miles.

column2: Anna, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been on this medication for almost 12 years now and I am doing great, I would like to go off someday, but I am afraid too, I don't want those feelings again.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Been on this med. for more than 2 years now. It's true as some said that doctors don't seem very informed about the full scope of side-effects of this drug, or they hesitate to tell because they're afraid to scare off the patients.:) My doctor only told me about having dry mouth & sweating more, but you probably agree that those are the least of concerns. I did look up more on all possible side-effects on the net; was shocked at how bad they can be, but since the med. did help me feel better mentally & emotionally (coupled with psychotherapy), I didn't bother trying to see how I'd do on other drugs. Doctor increased my dose slowly,& I experienced almost all the side-effects, particularly extreme drowsiness & fatigue. Now my dose is very slowly being reduced; had some mild withdrawal symptoms for about 10 days, & feeling so much better (less sleepy & tired) afterwards. Now on 112.5mg & things seem to be going pretty well. Good med. in general for me. Personally, I don't mind the withdrawal symptoms, though severe, as long as I can get rid of depression, which is a more serious concern to me & debilitate me more in all sense than any side-effects/ withdrawal symptoms, which are mainly physical.

column9: If you are on this medication, don't ever run out. It gives the worse feeling.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I did have some side effects while on effexor..sexual and weight issues.  I work out 5-6 times a week at the gym, and eat semi-healthy 80% of the time.  I couldn't figure out why I would gain instead of lose weight.  So I added a running regimen into my workouts....same thing- no lose of pounds.  In between all of that, my sexual desire went to nothing.  So, for the sake of my marriage I called my ob/gyn who put me on effexor for bad pms(I did ask to be put on something)  I was told my only option was to lower my dose, so we did.  I went back down to 75mg- then ot was no sleep, bad dreams,short-tempered.  So, I called back two weeks later and stated that I wanted to switch to a drug that had NO sexual side effects.  After 8 days, i finally got an answer(because of my moodiness, I had called 4 more times in that period)  I was told okat to switch, and I had asked for wellbutrin, since there was suppose to be no sexual side effects.  All good, until day 3- thats when the real bad moodiness, and lots of tears came in. 4th day dizzy, and nauseated all day.  My eyes had a glassy look to them.  Couldn't even stay the whole day at work.  Called my sister who is a pharmacist, and told her what was going on I SHOULD HAVE BEEN TAPERED OFF OF THE EFFEXOR!!!!  My doctor never said a word about it.  NEVER even mentioned that I might have drug withdrawals from the effexor.  I ended up having serious withdrawals- hot flashes, dizzy, nauseated, terrible lfe like dreams.Crying over nothing and everything.It was one of the WORST experiences I have ever been through. Today I am on day 12 of NO EFFEXOR!!!  I would never recommend this drug to anyone.  The drug withdrawals can last anywhere from 10 days to 3 weeks.  I had started taking the wellburtin, and on day 5 I called my doc. office crying, and the told be to add another half a pill.  I did, and now I want to be on nothing, so I am down to half a pill a day!!!!!  No drug should ever make a person feel that way.

column9: Completely eliminated depression, but if you miss a dose, or are late, you very quickly feel strong depression coming back. Side effect at 300mg per day - can never have ejaculation. At 150 per day (not enough for me), sex is halfway normal.

column2: alb, 45-54 on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have worked for several years with my doctor and mental health therapist to find ways to minimize the symptoms of chronic depression with exacerbations of seasonal affective disorder.  After much experimentation we hit on the combination of taking Wellbutrin year-round for the chronic depression and adding Effexor XR in varying doses throughout 9 months of the year to treat the seasonl affective disorder.  I start taking 37.5 mg of Effexor in the middle of August, increasing to 75 mg at the middle of October and to 112.5 mg at the end of November.  I maintain that dose all winter, until the beginning of April when I begin decreasing the dose at about 3-week intervals so that I'm off the Effexor by the middle of May.I have tried decreasing the dose more quickly than that, but like many others have reported, the side effects made me very uncomfortable.  (I have learned, when weaning off, to carry one 37.5 mg capsule with me to take if I'm feeling especially uncomfortable, but find I have rarely needed to take it.)While the medicine has been indispensable in relieving my suffering, I also must report the importance of behavioral interventions  showering and getting dressed every day, getting outside daily (even if its just to sit on the porch), calling or visiting friends when Im feeling down, and seeing my mental health therapist and/or doctor when Im feeling overwhelmed.  They help me to see how my thoughts may be contributing to the depression and how I can get back on track.If you are suffering, dont give up.  Try the interventions your doctor suggests, and let him or her know what works and what doesnt so that your treatment can be tailored to you.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was on Effexor 150mg for 2yrs. When I talked to my doctor about discontinuing use he put me on a "step down" pack.  One week at 75mg, then one week at 37.5mg then nothing.  At 75mg and 37.5mg I felt a little nausea, lightheadedness, and tired for a few days after starting each dose.  I too wondered what "brain zaps" were. I found out after the drug was out of my system. For one week I experienced what I could only describe as like "little seizures". Like little electrical "zaps" in my head & ears, accompanied by "zaps" of tingling sensations in my lips, face,neck and hands. I have never experienced anything like this, ever. I am now in week two..8 days off of the med., these symptoms seem to be getting gradually better.  Its been frightening. I have researched Effexor, trying to find info. about the withdrawal symptoms, but wouldn't you know it.. there's hardly any mention.."sensory symptoms". Effexor is an effective medication, but there should be more info. put out there to doctors,and patients about what happens when this drug is discontinued. I was told "flu like symptoms", not neurological disturbances, and I'm feeling pretty angry about that. There should be more straight forward patient information put out there by this drug mfr. Doctors need to be better educated about side effects of these types of meds, not just relying on the pharm. salesperson.

column2: AngelRules78, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I like what this medication has done for me. I suffered from Panic attacks after i discovered that I had heart and low/high blood pressure problems due to stress and exhaustion.  I call Effexor my happy pill. I "think" it did raise my blood pressure a little and i did gain some weight but not sure if i can blame the drug. It has NEVER affected my sex drive. I still have amazing gay sex at 30 years old :) But, missing a dose is BAD! It feels like a hangover and food poisoning. I don't know what missing more than one feels like but the thought absolutely terrifies me.  I've thought about weening off for months now since it ain't cheap and I really hate the idea of depending on this kind of drug. I keep reading the horror stories of brain zaps and months of withdrawal sypmtoms and I think I'd have to be broke and desparate to get off Effexor, especially after two years!  Not sure what to do...

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: When a dose is missed or trying to reduce dosage, the side effects are horrible, including headaches, irritablity, and dizziness or a feeling of electric shocks

column2: LadyRose, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Effexor for about 6 years. This has been a wonder drug for me although I do not have a sex drive, which in part is due to menopause, and I am unable to lose weight. I was dizzy and extremely tired. This week hasn't been quite as bad. I have one more week of the 75 mg. and then I drop to 37.5 for three weeks. Reading the other reviews has me concerned about the symptoms and do not quite understand what is meant by the "brain zaps.' Would appreciate it if someone would explain this.I have also noticed body aches and joint pain. Has anyone else?

column2: MGAVIN, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I WISHED I WOULD OF KNOWN ABOUT THIS MEDICATION MANY YEARS AGO. IT HAS CHANGED MY LIFE I AM A TOTAL HAPPPY PERSON FOR THE FIRST TIME IN YEARS!!

column9: I have been on many anxiety meds in the past all of which would leave me with extreme dizziness, nausea. I have just started the Effexor and am currently at 75mg in addition with Atarex and Klonipin 2 mgs. So far the tension in my head and neck have left and i can take a deep breath , finally. column2: LORIMM, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I took Effexor Xr 75mg for a year and loved it! I just had to wean myself off of it a couple of months ago because my insurance is changing and I can no longer afford it. I did have weird dreams when I first started taking it and I would sweat alot in my sleep. I'm assuming this was caused by the Effexor because I'm no longer having those problems. As far as weight gain, I lost and gained weight on it, so I believe it has no effect on weight. I believe I gained weight by eating lots of fast food and rarely exercising. I do believe it slowed down my weight lost process making it harder to lose weight. I start on Celexa tomorrow and hoping it works as well as Effexor!

column2: clbrgs, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on 150mg since 1999. Rather than make me feel better, it has made me not feel at all.  I finally realized how much I was missing in life because I could not enjoy things while taking this med, so my doctor is very slowly taking me off of it. I have quit taking it before, and because of life circumstances, I was put on it again.  The withdrawal I experienced from this med is unlike anything I ever experienced before.  I got all of the usual things; flu-like symptoms, brain shocks, anger, sadness, hopelessness, and more.  This time I am taking Geodon and Wellbutrin SR to help with the withdrawal.  It has helped quite a bit to take these meds!  I do still have some withdrawal symptoms, but not even close to as much as I had before.In all, I think that Effexor XR can be very helpful to a depressed person, but  people need to know about the withdrawal BEFORE they start it!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: As a collegiate athlete, initially this medication worked for me. Then, I begin to have anxiety attacks out of the blue. I was taken off this medication immediately. If you have ever had an anxiety attack, it feels just like the words suggest, AN ATTACK. That was the scariest feeling in my life. I was in Walmart doing what I normally do (look around) and instantly I felt beyond overwhelmed with all that was going on around me. I am so grateful that my roommate was with me. She was there to calm me and escort me back home. So, in a nutshell, I would say pay close attention to the side affects on this medication because they can pull you out of your element. I hope this helped.

column2: Oceanchild, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I wouldn't recommend Effexor for anyone. The drug just made me go crazy, I can't even explain it. With the mental condition I was in at the time of taking this, there was no room for the downslide I took from taking this drug. And the withdrawal when I stopped taking it was the worst experience I have ever been through.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This was the worst medacation I have ever taken my symptoms were dizziness, dry mouth, insomnia, loss of appetite, nausea, nervousness, sleepiness, sweating, and weakness,changed to elavil and didn't have half the problems.

column2: squeaky, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Effexor has worked great for me. However, I did experience weight gain,

column2: MAMA2, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I WAS PRESCRIBED THIS MEDICINE FOR ANXIETY SYMPTOMS THAT WERE RUINING MY DAILY ACTIVITIES, ESPECIALLY SLEEPING.  LACK OF SLEEP MADE THE ANXIETY MUCH WORSE.  WELL,  THE MEDICINE WAS NOT HARD TO TAKE AT ALL.  I HAD NO INITIAL SIDE EFFECTS AT ALL FROM THE DRUG.  AFTER READING MORE INFORMATION ABOUT ALL THE POTENTIAL SIDE EFFECTS, I DECIDED TO WEAN MYSELF FROM THIS MED.  BOY, THE TESTIMONIALS HERE ABOUT THE WITHDRAWAL SYMPTOMS ARE SOOOOO TRUE!  I EVEN BROKE DOWN EACH CAPSULE AND REMOVED A FEW MORE "BEADS" EACH DAY UNTIL I ONLY HAD A FEW LEFT.  THE SIDE EFFECTS WERE STILL HORRIBLE.  THE BRAIN ZAPS AND SHUDDERS WERE NOT PLEASANT AT ALL, IN FACT VERY DIZZYING.  I WILL DEFINITELY BE MORE AWARE OF SIDE EFFECTS BEFORE TAKING ANYTHING AFFECTING MY BRAIN!!!I FELT LIKE A TRUE SPACE CADET.  I AM CURREBNTLY NOT ON ANY MEDICATION THERAPY.  I'LL JUST DEAL WITH IT!

column2: lkbets, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed Effexor 150mg for menopausal symptoms and severe situational depression. It really helped me. Regretably my doctor never told me that there would be withdrawl symptoms until after I had been on the med. for 2 months. Since it was giving me my life back, I have stayed on it for 2yrs. I never planned on remaining on the drug forever, so after talking with my doctor, I have been "stepping down" over the past 2wks. I have 3 days left on 37.5 mg. then I'm done. I've had mild withdrawl symptoms such as fatique ,slight nausea, and lightheadedness.  Most often the symptoms are greatly minimized by late afternoon. Eventhough the med. really helped me get through a horrible time in my life I will be glad to be totally off of it.I will be all the wiser the next time I am prescribed medication for anything. I will make certain that I am knowledgable of a drugs side effects and potential for dependency before I ever start taking it, no matter how bennificial it may be. Instead of solely trusting the doctor to inform me.

column2: offmeds&amp;luvingit, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Hey Guys & Girls,It's been 3 weeks since I weaned myself off this drug.  The zaps are gone and so are all the "after shocks".  It helped while I was taking it, however, it wasn't suppose to be a long-term deal for me.  Be like a doctor and have "patience" while weaning off.  I'm so much happier now that I'm off meds.  Stay strong, blessings to all.

column2: Maggy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Hey Ya'll. Have been taking Effexor for 10 months. Am goin'thru the cold-turkey withdrawal stuff. It ain't pretty! Was diagnosed as being bi-polar/depressed when having anxiety over our $$$ woes. My doc sent me to a psych who wanted to put me on Trazadone for sleep, Stay on Effexor(75 mg.),and add 3 mg.Invega (the "new" lithium). Hmmm, well folks I felt like a zombie-just numb. No thanks, would rather feel sad or anything but that "zoned-out" thing. And really don't think I am bi-polar. Have never experienced that mania thing you read about where you don't sleep for days. Guess the best thing I have learned from this is get educated before you take anything. My doc did not discuss the withdrawal fun. Will be so glad when my ears quit ringing! And got so queasy on day 2 that I threw up a salad. Yuck. Am making a committment to myself to eat better and exercise. Work on my relationship with God, my husband, friends, and spoil my dogs. Try living in the moment and being thankful. This is what really works for me. Best of luck to all ya'll struggling with mood swings. Sending you happy thoughts!

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I've been on Effexor for 3.5 months (worked up to 150 mg / day over a period of 4 weeks) and I'm convinced it hasn't done anything for me moodwise.  I used to feel too tired and depressed to exercise, and it didn't help me.  It only made me want to eat more, and I gained about 20 lbs over that time period.  I am NOT prone to such weight gain. I've felt a bit better, but that's because my situation has changed and I've moved to a better place.  If I continue to gain weight, I will be really upset.  My clothes don't fit anymore.  I was really scared to stop the drugs, but since I moved I'm no longer on the same health care plan, so I can't see the doctor who prescribed Effexor.  I noticed that I didn't feel any side effects when I was late taking Effexor, so 3 days ago I thought I'd try to see what would happen if I waited a few more hours.  I felt none of the really frightening side effects that users on this site and others have reported.  I figure better to get off it before my body becomes dependant.  I did get some uncomfortable stomach cramping when eating dinner last night, so I took some pepto bismol and took about 1/3 of my 150 mg capsule and woke up feeling great.  More energy than I've had while on Effexor.  I'm scared that I'll feel some scary side effects soon, but so far, thank God, I feel fine.  I wouldn't recommend going cold turkey, as most folks seem to have experienced absolute hell.  I wonder why I was so lucky.

column2: dallen1432@comcast.net, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I only took this med for two weeks,only 37.5 mg.,after four days I started to have headaches,they became worse especially when I would go to bed at night,started to wean myself off this med,even though I knew I had not given myself enough time for my body to get used to this,have been off this med for two weeks and I still get on again-off again headaches,especially at bedtime when they are pounding,I take an excedrin at that usually helps,I never had headaches before taking this med,otherwise I feel o.k.,has anyone ever went through a situation like this?,especially considering I only took this for two weeks!,any feedback would be greatly appreciated.....

column2: Mollyest, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have suffered from anxiety, depression, panic, stress and alcoholism my entire adult life.  Four years ago, I began taking Prozac for depression and Klonopin for anxiety.  I did really well with that combination except for one thing: my sex drive died. As a result, I asked my Dr to change my medication, and he reluctantly changed me to Wellbutrin and Lexapro.  My sex drive returned but I was miserable.  I ended up in Detox.  After that, I tried Cymbalta and Amitriptyline which did not help and had bad side effects.  Finally, I tried Effexor.  Its a miracle.  The very next day I felt 'normal'....something I hadn't felt in years but instinctively knew was right.  I have experienced no weight gain with  Effexor, my sex drive has returned, and I am 15 months sober.  I want to make 3 points.  1)Effexor is great for ME, 2)don't give up until you find what's right for you...its worth it, 3) some side effects aren't as bad as you think if you weigh all the consequences (i.e. no sex drive would have been better than ending up in Detox).  Good Luck!

column2: Milo, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have tried a number of drugs for depression. I asked my doctor if I could try Effexor because of the profound effect it had on my sister. It has not had as drastic an effect on me, but I am functioning, and the depression is no longer debilitating as it once was. I take 300 mg. per day, and tried to go higher, but couldn't tolerate the side effects of a higher dose, esp. nausea. The downside is that I understand Effexor is a very difficult drug to stop taking (there is a "discontinuance syndrome"), so I'm likely to be on it for life.

column2: mellanie30, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: very bad medication!i was put on this medication back in 2004 for my 2nd child,it worked for about 17 months,it was doing me ok.then i noticed i was moody,short fused and i asked my shrink to put me on something else.i was on lexapro,welbutrin,cymbalta and those didn't work.so therefore seeming that the only thing did work for me my new shrink put me back on it again.in 2004 when i was on it,i HAD to be weaned off of,and i STILL had bad brain shocks and couldn't sleep for 4 months straight.so my new doc put me right back on this awful medication and now i'm resulting a addiction and when i get off this drug i WILL never go back on it.i am diagnosed with mild depression,add and fibromyolgia,as well as moderate anxiety

column2: Marledell, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: 7/23/08 Started Effexor 13yrs ago and now take 225mg daily. Prescribed for depression, anxiety, fibromyalgia, perimenopause. It has numbed me.  Side effects include: nightmares, much weight gain, blurred vision, loss of sex drive, confusion to the point of not being able to function, lost motivation. No longer want to be with people. Hard to feel any emotion except saddness/hopelessness. I'm certain it caused a problem with sleeping and got to the point that I was extremely fatigued.  Tests showed extremely low oxygen level when resting.  No energy.  Now sleep with a bi-pap machine which helps.  I was not overweight at the time. At first felt calm, but developed into talking too much, almost an excited/silly behavior that eventually passed after a few years. Tried to discontinue with the following side effects: extreme anxiety, anger over little things, aggressiveness,  crying spells, fearful (not my personality). I retired early due to not being able to function at my job. Now I feel really ignorant for not realizing the medication was causing many of these symptoms. I stayed on the drug because other meds hadn't worked for depression. My doctor said to ease off dosage by decreasing one pill per month.  Still horrible side effects and after two months of being completly off started back on meds.  You are asking why?  I just got tired of feeling so anxious and tearful or angry.  Not feeling was easier.  Guess I am very weak.  Am planning on changing doctors and again asking for help in discontinuing it.  I have a loving husband and children, but life is just too hard.

column2: dixie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Unlike Paxil, I did not have the side effects of the weight gain and the tiredness.  Effexor has no side effects for me even when the dose was doubled.  I am so pleased with this drug.

column2: mishac811, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Thank you to everybody who reviewed this drug. I thought I am going crazy - which is a pretty short ride for me. W/o Effexor- I just have panic atacks quite severe. BUT with Effexor, I got anxiety episodes - when I would worry about global warming, wars, weather -, vivid dreams/ nightmares which make Stephen King's books look like bedtime stories, debilitating physical symptoms - I would have to stay in bed for hours. Scarier though are the emotional and cognitive symptoms.I would feel like a stranger in my own body, in my own house and even in my own life. I never did drugs - but all the symptoms I have on Effexor are very close to what I imagine someone feels when stoned. BUT THE WORST IS I STARTED DRINKING - AND I NEVER IN MY LIFE HAD THIS PROBLEM. I FELT IN MY GUT THAT I AM NOT AN ALCOHOLIC, BUT COULDN'T EXPLAIN BEYOND THIS. AND I STARTED SMOKING AGAIN, ALTHOUGH I QUITTED 9 YR AGO. I want off this drug ASAP - anxiety and panic attacks are nothing compared to the living hell this med got me in.

I have been experiencing this for two weeks now and hope that it comes to an end soon!  How long does this last?

I got it filled, went back on my regular daily rutine, and my mind is now back in the order it belongs in.  I am aware it is my mistake but knowing it did not make my life any easier.  Moral of this story (Listen to your Doctor, and stay on your med's as they are prescribed)>

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I was on Effexor for about a year and a half. I was taking 150mg at breakfast and 75mg with supper. (225mg a day). I felt almost emotionless. Which could be a good thing for some. I recently quit taking effoxor because i didnt think i had deppression. Just anxiety.  I have been doing horrible. The brain shockls are unberable, I cannot think straight. I hate everhything. column2: Accordionlady,  Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Gynocologist prescribed it for hot flashes.  Stopped working after 3 months.  Increased dose.  Worked for another 3 months.  Increased dose.  Sweating UNBEARABLE!!!  Weight gain of some 30lbs after a little over a year of using it at 112.5mgs daily.  Tired constantly.  AWFUL!  Withdrawal was HELL and had to gradually come down over a 3 month period.  Left with weight to lose.  A real mess!!!!  NEVER would I recommend this to ANYONE!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Originally I started taking this to help my trichotillomania, but it didn't help.  Now I take this purely for my anxiety and can tell if I missed a day.  If I forget to take it I get all teary eyed and am more likely to just start crying for no reason.  I notice dizzyness and fatigue as a side effect.  I also notice I yawn more often.  I've been on the medication for about 4 years now and it's the only thing that's worked for me.

column2: sammyed, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Having been diagnosed with major depression in my teens and now almost 50, I have tried numerous antidepressants. Effexor is best, although I fall in to denial of needing medication at all. It's true it has side effects, especially when you try to go off it, but weaning and keeping to as low a dose as possible should be the norm for ANY med! It helped me more than Prozac because it is a SNRI and not just a SSRI. That makes a difference for me. I still cried a lot on Prozac and lost sleep. For us diehard depressives, the worst side effect of all is committing suicide, right? Effexor helped me feel positive and productive. My BP med is also necessary though it has side effects--beats having a stroke! Sure, sexual interest declines but that happens without meds, to me. I say be grateful for the medication advances of this era, it sure beats the 1970-80's or earlier! I do manage side effects of Effexor by staying on 75 rather than the 150 I was on, to feel less robotic, as I saw it. 300 certainly sounds like a big dose to me and I've been hospitalized with depression 3 times. When "weaning", give yourself at least 3-4 weeks to gradually go off. I laugh that it is like a nuclear reactor going on and coming off line. But I don't want to go hang from a tree anymore. One day, maybe I will show true acceptance and quit going off my meds!

column2: JerricaLee, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I am now trying to wean myself off of this horrible drug. I am taking Prozac in hopes that it will help with the withdrawal symptoms. I'm on day two and the brain zaps aren't too bad, but the emotional impact I feel from the withdrawal is overwhelming. I hope anyone reading this will try to get off this HORRIBLE NARCOTIC and try something else that may help with the withdrawal. I have been on Prozac before and never had any problems before, so I sure hope this works. My prayers to all of you that are suffering, this drug NEVER shoulf have been placed on the market. If you can, try Prozac to wean, I am on my second day and am down to 37.5 from 150 mg per day. W/O the Proazc, I would get the brain zaps after only ONE hour of not taking Effexor 150mg. I will keep you updated, keep trying everyone! If no one takes this horrible drug and we warn enough people, they will no longer make any money off of it! DO NOT TAKE THIS DRUG!!!

column2: Sharon, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I take 150 mg/daily for the "hot flashes" and moody feelings I have with the onset of Menopause. If I miss a couple of days I feel really edgy, have terrible headaches and want to hide.

column2: six, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I have been taking effexor now for 11 months. I lost my son 11 months ago so my doctor put me on this. I started out right off taking 6 a day. I can't tell I'm on anything. Everyelse I know takes 1 a day and can tell a difference. So why can't I?

column2: Keri, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: The medication is great when you first take it.  Totally made me feel better and my stress level went down considerably.  Side effect when taking the medication-no sex drive whatsoever.  The REAL problem is the side effects when you GET OFF the medicine.  I never knew that I was truly addicted to Effexor.  Basically, it is legal crack!  I had SEVERE "brain shocks" and headaches, restlessness, and my husband had to be my "nurse" for a month.  He seriously thought I was going crazy and needed mental help.  I can't describe the pain I was in.  Basically I was in bed all the time.  I was totally addicted, but luckily, I studied the internet and learned how doctors tell their patients to "ween" off the medicine.  1.  Weekly gradually taper down dosage.  (ex-Week one I went every other day 300mg and 150mg.  Week 2 I took 150mg daily.  Week 3 every other day 150mg and 75mg.  Week 4 I took 75mg daily.  Week 5 I went every other day 75mg and 0mg.  Week 6 I was Effexor free!  DO NOT suddenly stop taking this medication.  Hope this helps.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I took this medication for anxiety. I was on it for about a month and quit taking it all at once. I didnt have any of the symptoms of withdrawal others had except for the dizziness. I hated this med. It made me feel nauseated ALL the time. The sight or smell of food made me cringe. I lost 15 pounds, but this is not a good way to lose weight. I didnt want to leave the house. I am a very social person, but Effexor made me dread going anywhere. It helped me with anxiety but it made me not care about anything. I was completely emotionless. I didnt want to go anywhere, talk to anyone, or even eat. All I wanted to do was sleep or lay in the bed. NOT worth it!

column2: Cari, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Please read!  When looking at reviews, read comments made by people who have taken Effexor XR for a significant amount of time.  This more accurately explains side effects, etc.  I have taken Effexor 300mg for over 7 years.  While in the beginning it was a God sent, with time I'm learning that the side effects are horrible.  I tried to "ween" myself off this med, and was in the "brain shocks" were the worst pain possible.  I was bed-ridden for 3 weeks and ended up caving in.  I am still on the medicine today and once again am going to try and "ween" myself off-because I want to get pregnant.  I'm scared to once again go through the withdrawal, but it is the only choice I have.

column2: Reagan Robinson, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Besides the severe sweating all the type day and night, the medication works all month long except for during my PMS, during which time it is complete ineffective.

column2: on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years
column9: I have been taking 300 mg of Effexor XR for about a year.  For the past week I have been weaning myself down to 150 mg because of the side effects, mainly 0 sex drive.  I got my doctor to give me 75 mg caps instead of 150 mg caps.  I went down to 225 mg by only taking (3) 75 mg caps.  At the end of two weeks, I will go down 75 mg more, which will put me at 150 mg daily.  I have had no withdrawal sysmtoms doing it this way.

column2: Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)

The withdrawal symptoms aren't pretty either - at 225mg, your body will DEFINITELY let you know when you miss a dose.

column2: melanie, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: effexor has worked well for me,but it is awful when you try to get off of it.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Although I was a little worried about taking meds because I was afraid I would get "hooked" on them, I am so glad I took this medication. It has changed me. I am a more positive worry free person. I don't get afraid anymore. I used to have bad nervous panic attacks. I could not deal with negative and stressful issues at work. Now i am more livelier (my co-workers have noticed), I laugh more. Joke more and feel so much more RELAXED. Social gatherings are so much easier to be in. My hangups and fears are no minimal. As for side effects I did have headaches and blurred vision. Seems like the have subsided.. I only take the medication when I am "PMS"ing. I don't take it on a daily basis and my body does not feel side effect from that. Everyone is different Physiologically and tht is what we must understand!!!

column2: Swick4osu, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: DO NOT take this drug!  If only I had read these reviews first!  I started at 37.5 then up to 75...still had night sweats, still was irritable and now I have gained an additional 15 lbs or so in the 2 months I have taken this drug.  I also picked up restless leg syndrom, extremely vivid nightmares and absolutely no sex drive or ability to fullfill a sexual experience if you get my drift...this stuff is horrible.  so I started weening myself off by taking one every other day to finally off completely.  I have experienced severe dizziness, brain zingers, nausea but I discovered DRAMAMINE...it does not make the dizziness go away completely but it is at least tolerable and the nausea is gone.  I am focusing now on excercise and a completely healthy diet to avoid going through this ever again with any other magical pill a Dr. can prescribe....so I guess I could say Effexor helped me get a perspective on how important my health is and I am determined to self medicate through diet and excercise...  Good luck to all of you trying to get off this horrible horrible drug.

column2: Sundaygirl, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I don't really know how effective this medication would have been because I could not tolerate the side effects. column2: Living Again, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've been taking Effexor XR Oral for over 4yrs. for severe depression & anxiety. It has literally been a life-saver for me! column2: Lemeka , 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have never been on anything like this but I found that i was having trouble holding my tears back, worried all the time, lacked a sex drive. I also have suffered for years from extreme premenstrual pain due to sever e adhesions. Once I got past my first week and getting used to the drug it felt like a great weight was lifted off of me. I have had no side effects. But 1 thing that has astounded me is the relief from my premenstrual pain. I have been on it for 4 months and as each new month comes the pain is greatly lessened. my last period I had no pain what so ever. I had been on vicadone for pain just so I could sleep through the night and now I no longer need even iburpophen. Has anyone else had this happen?I want to scream it from the rooftops. But after reading the other comments I am worried about getting off of them if I need to. But at this point , if it keeps the debilitating pain away I will continue to take it.

column2: tbarnh, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)

column2: ginad, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: its really bad if you miss even 1 dose. i get sick as a dog . i have been trying to wean myself off of it but my body and mind cant handle it. not to mention the extreme eight gain since starting it but the medication has gotten me through alot of really bad times. im just scared ill have to be on it forever. but the drug does do its job for ex my husband begged me not to stop taking it emphasizing how much henoticed it has helped me

column2: Renne, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Get off these drugs!!I have been taking Trazodone for years to help with sleep and combat Fibromyalgia.  I was prescribed Effexor several years ago when the long Minnesota got to me. It was supposed to reduce the pain from the FMS also.  I have never gone above the minimum dose of 37.5 mg.  I have gradually gotten sicker and sicker and have gained a huge amount of weight. I have taken a circuitous route in searching for my health again and started a Ph balancing program which saved my life. I have been hearing bad things about SSRI's and really want off of them. Did you know that seratonin comes from the digestive track? Anyway,I stopped the meds and suffered horrible withdrawals! After 2 weeks I finally got some St. John's wart and doubled the dose.  It helped a bunch!  But just yesterday I listened to an audio by Ann Blake Tracy (www.drugawareness.org)which scared me into a different approach to wean off. It's day 2 of taking a reduced dose of Effexor and all of the physical health benefits I've gained in the past weeks are gone. Okay,  they just feel gone.  But it is critical that you wean off very slowly. If not,  the withdrawal can come back even 6 months later.  These drugs get out of the system but remain in the brain for several years.In summary, it helped for a short time.  But the long term effects are not worth it.  I am lucky to still be married.  And alive.

column1: Extreme Apprehension or Fear of Social Interaction

column9: I have had a few of the side effects, but can deal with them. I just can't cry! My father-in-law died and I felt really bad and was very sorry, but I could not cry.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: For about 3 years I was dealing with pain, mainly on my back and neck. This together with hot flashes, stomach cramps, bowel problems, and a sense of great fatigue. I thought it was all due to menopause. I had had a thyroid extraction 13 years ago due to cancer. Finally, one doctor told me I had a chemical imbalance and that Effexor would be good for me. I'm very pessimist what concerns medications, but after so much aggravation I decided to give it a try. In one week I had no pain, my 15 HF/day had gonne down to 2 or 3 (much milder though), and all the other symptoms desappeared. I miss one day and they all come back. I am on 75mg for 5 months now and the dr. didn't tell me nothing about increasing the dose. She did tell me I may start withdrawing from it after one year... I pray for that. If I will have to stay on it for the rest of my life (as I have to take my med for the thyroid everyday for the rest of my life) I'll do so. I have been having very vivid dreams, but none agressive or nightmares. Actually they are quite intricate and funny, like if I were watching a movie.I didn't put 5 starts for satisfaction because of all the reviews I've been reading and the problems with withdrawl. I surely won't be satisfied if I'll have so much trouble to get out of it!I do feel this drug is better for pshycosomatic illnesses than for mental ones only.
